question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We usually take time out only when we really need to
switch  off,  and  when  this  happens  we  are  often
overtired, sick, and in need of recuperation. Me time is
complicated by <u>negative associations with escapism,
guilt,  and  regret  as  well  as  overwhelm,  stress,  and
fatigue.</u> All these negative connotations mean we tend
to steer  <u>clear of it.</u> Well, I am about to change your
perception of the importance of me time, to persuade
you that you should view it as  <u>the trivial for your
health and wellbeing.</u> Take this as permission to  <u>set
aside  some  time  for  yourself!</u>  Our  need  for  time  in
which to do what we choose is increasingly  <u>urgent in
an  overconnected,  overwhelmed,  and  overstimulated
world.</u>
*recuperation: 회복

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps  <u>worse than attempting to get the bad news
out of the way is attempting to soften it or simply not
address it at all.</u> This “Mum Effect” — a term coined by
psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in the
early  1970s  —  happens  <u>because  people  want  to
avoid  becoming  the  target  of  others’  negative
emotions.</u> We all have the opportunity to lead change,
yet it often requires of us the courage to deliver bad
news  to  our  superiors.  <u>We  don’t  want  to  be  the
innocent  messenger  who  falls  before  a  firing  line.</u>
When  our  survival  instincts  kick  in,  <u>they  can
override our courage until the truth of a situation gets
watered  down.</u>  “The  Mum  Effect  and  the  resulting
filtering  can  have  devastating  effects  in  a  steep
hierarchy,”  writes  Robert  Sutton,  an  organizational
psychologist. “What starts out as bad news becomes
happier  and  happier  as  it  travels  up  the  ranks  ―
because after each boss hears the news from his or
her subordinates,  <u>he or she makes it sound a bit
more bad before passing it up the chain.</u>”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Most  parents  think  that  if  our  child  would  just
“behave,” we could stay calm as parents. The truth is
that  <u>regulating  our  own  emotions  and  actions  is
what allows us to feel peaceful as parents.</u> Ultimately
we can’t control our children or the obstacles they will
face ―but we can always  <u>manage our own actions.</u>
Parenting isn’t about what our child does, but about
how  we  <u>neglect.</u>  In  fact,  most  of  what  we  call
parenting  doesn’t  take  place  between  a  parent  and
child but within the parent. When a storm  <u>builds up,
a parent’s response will either calm it or trigger a full‐
scale  tsunami.</u>  Staying  calm  enough  to  respond
constructively to all that childish behavior ― and the
stormy  emotions  behind  it  ―requires  that  we  grow,
too. If we can use those times when our buttons get
pushed to reflect, not just react, we can notice when
we  <u>are out of control and steer ourselves back on
track.</u> This inner growth is the hardest work there is,
but it’s what enables you to become a more peaceful
parent, one day at a time.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?(2개)
mainText:
We  have  already  seen  that  learning  is  much  more
efficient when done at  <u>regular intervals: rather than
cramming an entire lesson into one day, we are better
off spreading out the learning.</u> The reason is simple:
every  night,  <u>our  brain  consolidates  what  it  has
learned  during  the  day.</u>  This  is  one  of  the  most
important  neuroscience  discoveries  of  the  last  thirty
years:  sleep  is  not  just  a  period  of  <u>activity  or  a
garbage collection of the waste products that the brain
accumulated while we were awake.</u> Quite the contrary:
while we sleep, our brain remains  <u>inactive; it runs a
specific algorithm that replays the important events it
recorded  during  the  previous  day  and  gradually</u>
<u>transfers them into a more efficient compartment of
our memory.</u>
* consolidate: 통합 정리하다
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장 적

question: 절한 것은?
mainText:
From the earliest times, healthcare services have been
recognized to have two equal aspects, namely clinical
care  and  public  healthcare.  In  classical  Greek
mythology,  the  god  of  medicine,  Asklepios,  had  two
daughters, Hygiea and Panacea. The former was the
goddess of preventive health and wellness, or hygiene,
and the latter the goddess of treatment and curing. In
modern  times,  the  societal  ascendancy  of  medical
professionalism has caused treatment of sick patients
to  overshadow  those  preventive  healthcare  services
provided by the (A)  [more  /  less] heroic figures of
sanitary engineers, biologists, and governmental public
health officers. Nevertheless, the quality of health that
human populations enjoy is attributable (B)  [less  /
more] to surgical dexterity, innovative pharmaceutical
products,  and  bioengineered  devices  than  to  the
availability of public sanitation, sewage management,
and  services  which  control  the  pollution  of  the  air,
drinking  water,  urban  noise,  and  food  for  human
consumption.  The  human  right  to  the  highest (C)
[attainable  /  unachievable]  standard  of  health
depends on public healthcare services no less than on
the skills and equipment of doctors and hospitals.  
*ascendancy: 우세 **dexterity: 기민함
 <u>less - less - attainable</u> <u>less - less - unachievable</u> <u>more - less - unachievable</u> <u>less - more - unachievable</u> <u>more - more - attainable</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
By noticing the relation between their own actions and
resultant  external  changes,  infants  develop  self‐
efficacy, a sense that they are agents of the perceived
 <u>changes.</u> Although infants can notice the effect of
their  behavior  on  the  physical  environment,  it  is  in
early  social  interactions  that  infants  most  readily 
<u>perceive the consequence of their actions.</u> People have
perceptual  characteristics  that  virtually  assure  that
infants  will  orient  toward  them.  They  have  visually
contrasting  and  moving  faces.  They  produce  sound,
provide touch, and have interesting smells. In addition,
people  <u>engage with infants by exaggerating their
facial expressions and inflecting their voices in ways
that  infants  find  fascinating.</u>  But  most  importantly,
these  antics  are  responsive  to  infants’  vocalizations,
facial expressions, and gestures; people  <u>fix the pace
and  level  of  their  behavior  in  response  to  infant
actions.</u>  Consequentially,  early  social  interactions
provide a context where infants can easily  <u>notice the
effect of their behavior.</u>
* inflect: (음성을) 조절하다 ** antics: 익살스러운 행동

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adam  Smith  pointed  out  that  specialization,  where
each  of  us  focuses  on  one  specific  skill,  leads  to  a
general improvement of everybody’s well‐being. The
idea is simple and powerful. By specializing in just one
activity ―such as food raising, clothing production, or
home  construction  ―  each  worker  <u>gains  mastery
over  the  particular  activity.</u>  Specialization  makes
sense, however, only if the specialist can subsequently
trade his or her output with the  <u>output of specialists
in other lines of activity.</u> It would make no sense to
produce more food than a household needs  <u>if there
is  a  market  outlet  to  exchange  that  excess  food  for
clothing,  shelter,  and  so  forth.</u>  At  the  same  time,
without the ability to buy food on the market, it would
not be  <u>possible to be a specialist home builder or
clothing maker, since it would be necessary to farm for
one’s  own  survival.</u>  Thus  Smith  realized  that  the
division  of  labor  is  <u>limited  by  the  extent  of  the
market,  whereas  the  extent  of  the  market
is determined by the degree of specialization.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장 적

mainText:
It  is  not  the  peasant's  goal  to  produce  the  highest
possible time‐averaged crop yield, averaged over many
years. If your time‐averaged yield is marvelously high
as a result of the combination of nine great years and
one year of crop failure, you will still starve to death in
that one year of crop failure before you can look back to
congratulate yourself on your great time-averaged yield.
Instead, the peasant's aim is to make sure to produce a
yield (A)[above / below] the starvation level in every
single year, even though the time-averaged yield may
not  be  highest.  That's  why  field  scattering  may  make
sense. If you have just one big field, no matter how (B)
[bad / good] it is on the average, you will starve when
the inevitable occasional year arrives in which your one
field  has  a  low  yield.  But  if  you  have  many  different
fields, varying independently of each other, then in any
given year some of your fields will produce (C)[well  /
badly] even when your other fields are producing poorly.
 <u>above - bad - well</u> <u>below - bad - badly</u> <u>above - good - badly</u> <u>below - good - badly</u> <u>above - good - well</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
There  are  several  reasons  why  support  may  not  be
effective. One possible reason is that  <u>receiving help
could  be  a  blow  to  self‐esteem.</u>  A  recent  study  by
Christopher  Burke  and  Jessica  Goren  at  Lehigh
University examined this possibility. According to the
threat to self‐esteem model, help can be perceived as
supportive and loving, or it can be seen as threatening
if that help is interpreted as implying  <u>competence.</u>
According  to  Burke  and  Goren,  support  is  especially
likely to be seen as threatening if it is in an area that is
self‐relevant  or  self‐defining  —  that  is,  in  an  area
where  your  own  success  and  achievement  are
especially  <u>important.</u>  Receiving  help  with  a  self‐
relevant task can make you feel bad about yourself,
and this can  <u>undermine the potential positive effects
of the help.</u> For example, if your self‐concept rests, in
part, on your great cooking ability, it may be a blow to
your ego when a friend helps you prepare a meal for
guests  because  it  suggests  that  you’re  not  the 
<u>master chef you thought you were.</u>

As  well  as  <u>making  sense  of  events  through
narratives, historians in the ancient world established
the tradition of history as a source of moral lessons
and reflections.</u> The history writing of Livy or Tacitus,
for  instance,  was  in  part  designed  to  examine  the
behavior of heroes and villains,  <u>mediating on the
strengths  and  weaknesses  in  the  characters  of
emperors and generals, providing exemplars for</u> <u>the
virtuous to imitate or avoid.</u> This continues to be one
of  the  functions  of  history.  French  chronicler  Jean
Froissart  said  he  had  written  his  <u>accounts  of
chivalrous knights fighting in the Hundred Years’ War
“so that brave men should</u> <u>be inspired thereby to
follow  such  examples.</u>”  Today,  historical  studies  of
Lincoln,  Churchill,  Gandhi,  or  Martin  Luther  King,  Jr.
perform the same function.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?(2개)
mainText:
Psychologist  Christopher  Bryan  finds  that  when  we
shift our emphasis from behavior to  <u>figure, people
evaluate choices differently.</u> His team was able to cut
cheating in half: instead of “Please don’t cheat,” they
changed the appeal to “Please don’t  <u>be a cheater.</u>”
When you’re urged not to cheat, you can do it and still
see an ethical person in the mirror. But when you’re
told not to be a cheater, the act casts a shadow; 
<u>mortality is tied to your identity, making the behavior
much  less  attractive.</u>  Cheating  is  an  isolated  action
that gets evaluated with the logic of consequence: Can
I get away with it? Being a cheater evokes a sense of
self, triggering the logic of  <u>appropriateness: What
kind of person am I, and who do I want to be?</u> In light
of  this  evidence,  Bryan  suggests  that  we  should
embrace  <u>verbs more thoughtfully.</u> “Don’t Drink and
Drive”  could  be  rephrased  as:  “Don’t  Be  a  Drunk
Driver.” The same thinking can be applied to originality.
When  a  child  draws  a  picture,  instead  of  calling  the
artwork creative, we can say “You are creative.”
text:

changed the appeal to “Please don’t  <u>be a cheater.</u>”

that gets evaluated with the logic of consequence: Can

kind of person am I, and who do I want to be?</u> In light
of  this  evidence,  Bryan  suggests  that  we  should
embrace  <u>verbs more thoughtfully.</u> “Don’t Drink and
Drive”  could  be  rephrased  as:  “Don’t  Be  a  Drunk

When  a  child  draws  a  picture,  instead  of  calling  the
artwork creative, we can say “You are creative.”

evaluate choices differently.</u>

③ <u>mortality is tied to your identity, making the behavior

④ <u>appropriateness: What

explanation: 1) 당신이 속이지 말라고 강요받을 때, 당신은 속일 수 있고, 여전히 거울 속에서 도덕적인 사람을 볼 수 있다고 하였으므로 ③은 immorality로 고쳐야 한다. (mortality 죽을 운 명) 2) 다음 문장에서 ''Don't Drink and Drive''를 "Don't be a Drunk Driver."로 바꿔 표현한 문장에서 동사 대신 명사 표현을 사용하는 예를 통해서 행동보다 인격을 강조할 때, 사람들이 선택 을 다르게 평가한다는 흐름이 적절하므로 ⑤ 'verbs' 를 nouns로 고쳐야 한다. <변형 포인트 ①character->figure>

Taking  a  stand  is  important  because  you  become  a
beacon for those individuals who are your people, your
tribe,  and  your  audience.  When  you  <u>lift  your
viewpoint  up  like  a  flag,  people  know  where  to  find
you;   it   becomes   a   rallying   point.</u> 
<u>Demonstrating your perspective lets prospective (and
current) customers know that you don’t just sell your
products or services.</u> The best marketing is never just
about selling a product or service, but about taking a
stand  —  <u>showing  an  audience  why  they  should
believe in what you’re marketing enough to want it at
any cost, simply because they</u> <u>acknowledge what
you’re doing.</u> Products can be changed or adjusted if
they  aren’t  functioning,  but  rallying  points  are 
<u>separate  from  the  values  and  meaning  behind  what
you do.</u>
*beacon: 횃불 **rallying point: 집합 지점
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
If DNA were the only thing that mattered, there would
be  no  particular  reason  to  build  meaningful  social
programs to pour good experiences into children and
protect them from bad experiences. But brains require
the right kind of environment if they are to correctly
develop. When the first draft of the Human Genome
Project  came  to  completion  at  the  turn  of  the
millennium,  one  of  the  great  surprises  was  that
humans have only about twenty thousand genes. This
number came as a surprise to biologists: given the (A)
[complexity / simplicity] of the brain and the body,
it had been assumed that hundreds of thousands of
genes would be required. So how does the massively
complicated brain, with its eighty‐six billion neurons,
get  built  from  such  a (B)  [large  /  small]  recipe
book?  The  answer  relies  on  a  clever  strategy
implemented by the genome: build (C) [completely /
incompletely] and let world experience refine.
 <u>complexity - small - completely</u> <u>complexity - small - incompletely</u> <u>simplicity - small - completely</u> <u>simplicity - large - incompletely</u> <u>complexity - large - completely</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
One benefit of reasons and arguments is that they can
foster  humility.  If  two  people  <u>disagree without
arguing, all they do is yell at each other.</u> No progress is
made. Both still think that they are right. In contrast, if
both  sides  give  arguments  that  articulate  reasons  for
their positions, then new possibilities open up. One of the
arguments gets  <u>refuted - that is, it is shown to fail.</u> In
that  case,  the  person  who  depended  on  the  refuted
argument learns that he needs to  <u>maintain his view.</u>
That is one way to achieve humility - on one side at
least.  Another  possibility  is  that  neither  argument  is
refuted. Both have a degree of reason on their side. Even
if  neither  person  involved  is  convinced  by  the  other's
argument,  both  can  still  come  to  <u>appreciate the
opposing view.</u> They also realize that, even if they have
some truth, they do not have the whole truth. They can
gain  humility  when  they  recognize  and  appreciate  the
reasons  <u>against their own view.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the  next.  This  is  different  from  acclimation  —  an
individual organism’s changes in response to an altered
environment. For example, if you spend the summer
outside, you may  <u>acclimate to the sunlight: your
skin  will  increase  its  concentration  of  dark  pigments
that  protect  you  from  the  sun.</u>  This  is  a 
<u>transient change, and you won’t pass the temporary
change  on  to  future  generations.</u>  However,  the
 <u>capacity to produce skin pigments is inherited.</u> For
populations  living  in  intensely  sunny  environments,
individuals  with  a  good  ability  to  produce  skin
pigments are more likely to  <u>flourish, than people
with a poor ability to produce pigments, and that trait
becomes   increasingly   common   in   subsequent
generations.</u> If you look around, you can find countless
examples of adaptation. The distinctive long neck of a
giraffe,  for  example,  developed  as  individuals  that
happened to have longer necks had a  <u>drawback in
feeding on the leaves of tall trees.</u> 
* pigment: 색소
text:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the  next.  This  is  different  from  acclimation  —  an
individual organism’s changes in response to an altered
environment. For example, if you spend the summer
outside, you may  <u>acclimate to the sunlight: your
skin  will  increase  its  concentration  of  dark  pigments
that  protect  you  from  the  sun.</u>  This  is  a 
<u>transient change, and you won’t pass the temporary
change  on  to  future  generations.</u>  However,  the
 <u>capacity to produce skin pigments is inherited.</u> For
populations  living  in  intensely  sunny  environments,
individuals  with  a  good  ability  to  produce  skin
pigments are more likely to  <u>flourish, than people
with a poor ability to produce pigments, and that trait
becomes   increasingly   common   in   subsequent
generations.</u> If you look around, you can find countless
examples of adaptation. The distinctive long neck of a
giraffe,  for  example,  developed  as  individuals  that
happened to have longer necks had a  <u>drawback in
feeding on the leaves of tall trees.</u> 
* pigment: 색소

skin  will  increase  its  concentration  of  dark  pigments

change  on  to  future  generations.</u>

④ <u>flourish, than people
with a poor ability to produce pigments, and that trait
becomes   increasingly   common   in   subsequent

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
On any day of the year, the tropics and the hemisphere
that is experiencing its warm season receive much more
solar radiation than do the polar regions and the colder
hemisphere. Averaged over the course of the year, the
tropics and latitudes up to about 40' receive  <u>more
total heat than they lose by radiation.</u> Latitudes above
40' receive less total heat than they lose by radiation.
This  <u>inequality produces the necessary conditions for
the operation of a huge, global-scale engine that takes
on heat in the tropics and gives it off in the polar regions.</u>
Its working  <u>fluid is the atmosphere, especially the
moisture  it  contains.</u>  Air  is  <u>heated over  the  warm
earth of the tropics, expands, rises, and flows away both
northward and southward at high altitudes, cooling as it
goes.</u> It descends and flows  <u>from the equator again
from more northerly and southerly latitudes.</u>
*latitude: 위도

question: 다음 글의 괄호 (A), (B), (C) 안에서 문맥에 맞는 표현으 로 가장 적절한 것은?
mainText:
Greenwashing  involves  misleading  a  consumer  into
thinking  a  good  or  service  is  more  environmentally
friendly  than  it  really  is.  Greenwashing  ranges  from
making  environmental  claims  required  by  law,  and
therefore  irrelevant  (CFC-free  for  example),  to  puffery
(exaggerating   environmental   claims)   to   fraud.
Researchers  have  shown  that  claims  on  products  are
often too (A) [unclear / distinct] or misleading. Some
products  are  labeled  “chemical-free,”  when  the  fact  is
everything  contains  chemicals,  including  plants  and
animals. Products with the highest number of misleading
or  unverifiable  claims  were  laundry  detergents,
household cleaners, and paints. Environmental advocates
agree there is still a long way to go to ensure shoppers
are (B) [correctly / incompletely] informed about the
environmental impact of the products they buy. The most
common  reason  for  greenwashing  is  to  attract
environmentally conscious consumers. Many consumers
do  not  find  out  about  the  false  claims  until  after  the
purchase.  Therefore,  greenwashing  may  increase  sales
(C)  [momentarily  /  consistently].  However,  this
strategy  can  seriously  backfire  when  consumers  figure
out they are being deceived.
 <u>unclear - correctly - momentarily</u> <u>unclear - incompletely - consistently</u> <u>distinct - correctly - consistently</u> <u>distinct - incompletely - momentarily</u> <u>distinct - correctly - momentarily</u>

options: ① <u>unclear - correctly - momentarily</u>
② <u>unclear - incompletely - consistently</u>
③ <u>distinct - correctly - consistently</u>
④ <u>distinct - incompletely - momentarily</u>

explanation: (A) 화학물질이 있음에도 없다고 표기되는 일부 제 품들에 대한 언급이 이어지고, misleading과 같은 맥락이어야 하 므로, unclear(불확실한)가 적절하다. distinct: 뚜렷한 (B) 현혹 적이고 확인할 수 없는 주장이 포함된 제품들이 앞에서 언급되었 고, 소비자들은 구매가 완료되고 난 후에야 거짓 주장을 알아차린 다고 했으므로, 환경 옹호자들은 소비자들이 자신이 구매하는 제 품의 환경적 영향력에 대해 올바른 정보를 받도록 확실히 해야 한 다는 흐름이 자연스럽다. 따라서, correctly(올바르게)가 알맞다. incompletely: 불완전하게 (C) 환경적으로 의식이 있는 소비자들 을 유인하는 그린워싱은, 판매는 일시적으로 증가될 것이므로 momentarily(잠시)가 올바르다. consistently: 지속적으로

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We usually take time out only when we really need to
switch  off,  and  when  this  happens  we  are  often
overtired, sick, and in need of  <u>recuperation.</u> Me time
is complicated by negative associations with escapism,
guilt,  and  regret  as  well  as  overwhelm,  stress,  and
fatigue. All these negative connotations mean we tend
to  <u>avoid  it.</u>  Well,  I  am  about  to  change  your
perception  of  the  importance  of  me  time,  to 
<u>persuade you that you should view it as vital for your
health and wellbeing.</u> Take this as  <u>prohibition to set
aside  some  time  for  yourself!</u>  Our  need  for  time  in
which to do what we choose is increasingly  <u>urgent in
an  overconnected,  overwhelmed,  and  overstimulated
world.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news
out of the way is attempting to soften it or simply not
address it at all. This “Mum Effect” — a term  <u>coined
by psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in
the early 1970s — happens because people want to</u>
<u>avoid  becoming  the  target  of  others’  negative
emotions.</u> We all have the opportunity to lead change,
yet it often requires of us the courage to deliver bad
news  to  our  superiors.  We  don’t  want  to  be  the
innocent  messenger  who  falls  before  a  firing  line.
When  our  survival  instincts  kick  in,  they  can 
<u>override our courage until the truth of a situation gets
watered  down.</u>  “The  Mum  Effect  and  the  resulting
filtering  can  have  <u>devastating  effects  in  a  steep
hierarchy,”  writes  Robert  Sutton,  an  organizational
psychologist.</u> “What starts out as bad news becomes
happier  and  happier  as  it  travels  up  the  ranks  ―
because after each boss hears the news from his or
her subordinates, he or she makes it sound a bit 
<u>worse before passing it up the chain.</u>”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Most parents think that if our child would just "behave,"
we  could  stay  calm  as  parents.  The  truth  is  that
managing our own emotions and actions is what allows
us  to  feel  peaceful  as  parents.  Ultimately  we  can't
 <u>control our children or the obstacles they will face —
but  we  can  always  control  our  own  actions.</u>  Parenting
isn't  about  what  our  child  does,  but  about  how  we
 <u>respond.</u>  In  fact,  most  of  what  we  call  parenting
doesn't take place between a parent and child but within
the parent. When a storm brews, a parent's response will
either calm it or trigger a full scale tsunami. Staying calm
enough to respond constructively to all that  <u>mature
behavior — and the stormy emotions behind it requires
that we grow, too.</u> If we can use those times when our
buttons get pushed to reflect, not just  <u>react, we can
notice when we lose equilibrium and steer ourselves back
on track.</u> This inner growth is the hardest work there is,
but it's what enables you to become a more  <u>peaceful
parent, one day at a time.</u>

We have already seen that learning is much more 
<u>efficient  when  done  at  regular  intervals:  rather  than
cramming an entire lesson into one day, we are better
off spreading out the learning.</u> The reason is simple:
every  night,  our  brain  <u>consolidates  what  it  has
learned  during  the  day.</u>  This  is  one  of  the  most
important  neuroscience  discoveries  of  the  last  thirty
years:  sleep  is  not  just  a  period  of  inactivity  or  a
garbage collection of the waste products that the brain
accumulated while we were awake. Quite the contrary:
while we sleep, our brain remains  <u>active; it runs a
specific  algorithm  that</u> <u>removes  the  important
events  it  recorded  during  the  previous  day  and</u>
<u>gradually  transfers  them  into  a  more  efficient
compartment of our memory.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
From the earliest times, healthcare services have been
recognized to have two equal aspects, namely clinical
care  and  public  healthcare.  In  classical  Greek
mythology,  the  god  of  medicine,  Asklepios,  had  two
daughters, Hygiea and Panacea. The former was the
goddess of preventive health and wellness, or hygiene,
and the latter the goddess of treatment and curing. In
modern times, the societal  <u>ascendancy of medical
professionalism has caused treatment of sick patients</u> <u>to overshadow those preventive healthcare services
provided  by  the</u> <u>less  heroic  figures  of  sanitary
engineers, biologists, and governmental public health
officers.</u> Nevertheless, the quality of health that human
populations enjoy is attributable  <u>more to surgical
dexterity,  innovative  pharmaceutical  products,  and
bioengineered devices than to the availability of public
sanitation,  sewage  management,  and  services  which
control the pollution of the air, drinking water, urban
noise, and food for human consumption.</u> The human
right  to  the  highest  attainable  standard  of  health
depends on public healthcare services  <u>no less than
on the skills and equipment of doctors and hospitals.</u>  
*ascendancy: 우세 **dexterity: 기민함
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 쓰임에 맞는 낱말로 가장

and the latter the goddess of treatment and curing. In
modern times, the societal  <u>ascendancy of medical
professionalism has caused treatment of sick patients</u> <u>to overshadow those preventive healthcare services
provided  by  the</u> <u>less  heroic  figures  of  sanitary
engineers, biologists, and governmental public health
officers.</u> Nevertheless, the quality of health that human
populations enjoy is attributable  <u>more to surgical
dexterity,  innovative  pharmaceutical  products,  and
bioengineered devices than to the availability of public
sanitation,  sewage  management,  and  services  which
control the pollution of the air, drinking water, urban
noise, and food for human consumption.</u> The human
right  to  the  highest  attainable  standard  of  health
depends on public healthcare services  <u>no less than
on the skills and equipment of doctors and hospitals.</u>

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
By noticing the relation between their own actions and
resultant  external  changes,  infants  develop  self‐
efficacy, a sense that they are agents of the perceived
changes. Although infants can notice the effect of their
behavior  on  the  physical  environment,  it  is  in  early
social  interactions (A)  [what  /  that]  infants  most
readily  perceive  the  consequence  of  their  actions.
People  have  perceptual  characteristics  that  virtually
assure that infants will orient toward them. They have
visually  contrasting  and  moving  faces.  They  produce
sound, provide touch, and have interesting smells. (B)
[In addition / In other words], people engage with
infants  by  exaggerating  their  facial  expressions  and
inflecting  their  voices  in  ways  that  infants  find
fascinating.  But  most  importantly,  these  antics  are
responsive to infants’ vocalizations, facial expressions,
and gestures; people vary the pace and level of their
behavior (C)  [in  response  to  /  in  contrast  to]
infant actions. Consequentially, early social interactions
provide a context where infants can easily notice the
effect of their behavior.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adam  Smith  pointed  out  that  specialization,  where
each  of  us  focuses  on  one  specific  skill,  leads  to  a
general improvement of everybody’s well‐being. The
idea is simple and powerful. By specializing in just one
activity ―such as food raising, clothing production, or
home construction ― each worker gains mastery over
 <u>various  activities.</u>  Specialization  makes  sense,
however, only if the specialist can subsequently trade
his or her output with the output of specialists in other
lines of activity. It would make no sense to  <u>produce
more food than a household needs unless there is a
market</u> <u>outlet  to  exchange  that  excess  food  for
clothing,  shelter,  and  so  forth.</u>  At  the  same  time,
without the ability to buy food on the market, it would
not  be  possible  to  be  a  specialist  home  builder  or
clothing maker, since it would be  <u>necessary to farm
for one’s own survival.</u> Thus Smith realized that the 
<u>division of labor is limited by the extent of the market,
whereas the extent of the market is determined by the
degree of specialization.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It  is  not  the  peasant's  goal  to  produce  the  highest
possible time averaged crop yield, averaged over many
years. If your time averaged yield is  <u>marvelously
high as a result of the combination of nine great years
and  one  year  of  crop  failure,  you  will  still  starve  to
death in that one year of crop</u> <u>failure before you can
look back to congratulate yourself on your great time
averaged yield.</u> Instead, the peasant's aim is to make
sure to produce a yield  <u>above the starvation level in
every single year, even though the time averaged yield
may not be highest.</u> That's why field scattering may
make sense. If you have just one big field, no matter
how good it is on the average, you will starve when the
 <u>inevitable occasional year arrives in which your one
field has a low yield.</u> But if you have many different
fields, varying  <u>dependently of each other, then in
any given year some of your fields will produce well
even when your other fields are producing poorly.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
There are several reasons why support may not be 
<u>effective.</u>  One  possible  reason  is  that  receiving  help
could be a  <u>threat to self‐esteem.</u> A recent study by
Christopher  Burke  and  Jessica  Goren  at  Lehigh
University examined this possibility. According to the
threat to self‐esteem model, help can be perceived as
supportive and loving, or it can be seen as threatening
if that help is interpreted as implying  <u>incompetence.</u>
According  to  Burke  and  Goren,  support  is  especially
likely to be seen as  <u>helpful if it is in an area that is
self‐relevant  or  self‐defining  —  that  is,  in  an  area
where  your  own  success  and  achievement  are
especially  important.</u>  Receiving  help  with  a  self‐
relevant task can make you feel bad about yourself,
and this can  <u>undermine the potential positive effects
of the help.</u> For example, if your self‐concept rests, in
part, on your great cooking ability, it may be a blow to
your ego when a friend helps you prepare a meal for
guests because it suggests that you’re not the master
chef you thought you were.

question: 다음 글의 괄호 (A), (B), (C)에 들어갈 말로 알맞은 것은?
mainText:
As well as making sense of events through narratives,
historians  in  the  ancient  world (A)[estimated   /
established] the  tradition  of  history  as  a  source  of
moral lessons and reflections. The history writing of Livy
or Tacitus, for instance, was in part designed to examine
the behavior of heroes and villains, (B)[meditating  /
mediating]  on  the  strengths  and  weaknesses  in  the
characters  of  emperors  and  generals,  providing
exemplars  for  the  virtuous  to  imitate  or  avoid.  This
continues to be one of the functions of history. French
chronicler Jean Froissart said he had written his accounts
of chivalrous knights fighting in the Hundred Years' War
"so that brave men should be (C)[inspired / expired]
thereby  to  follow  such  examples."  Today,  historical
studies  of  Lincoln,  Churchill,  Gandhi,  or  Martin  Luther
King, Jr. perform the same function.
 <u>estimated - meditating - expired</u> <u>estimated - mediating - expired</u> <u>established - meditating - expired</u> <u>established - mediating - inspired</u> <u>established - meditating - inspired</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Psychologist  Christopher  Bryan  finds  that  when  we
 <u>emphasize character rather than behavior, people
evaluate choices differently.</u> His team was able to cut
cheating in half: instead of “Please don’t cheat,” they
changed  the  appeal  to  “Please  don’t  be  a  cheater.”
When you’re  <u>advised not to cheat, you can do it and
still  see  an  ethical  person  in  the  mirror.</u>  But  when
you’re told not to be a cheater, the act casts a shadow;
immorality is tied to your identity, making the behavior
much less  <u>desirable.</u> Cheating is an isolated action
that gets evaluated with the logic of consequence: Can
I get away with it? Being a cheater  <u>evokes a sense
of self, triggering the logic of appropriateness: What
kind of person am I, and who do I want to be?</u> In light
of  this  evidence,  Bryan  suggests  that  we  should
 <u>exclude nouns more thoughtfully.</u> “Don’t Drink and
Drive”  could  be  rephrased  as:  “Don’t  Be  a  Drunk
Driver.” The same thinking can be applied to originality.
When  a  child  draws  a  picture,  instead  of  calling  the
artwork creative, we can say “You are creative.”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Taking  a  stand  is  important  because  you  become  a
beacon for those individuals who are your people, your
tribe,  and  your  audience.  When  you  <u>raise  your
 viewpoint up like a flag, people know where to find
you;  it  becomes  a  rallying  point.</u>  Displaying  your
perspective  lets  prospective  (and  current)  customers
know  that  you  don’t   just  sell  your  products  or
services.  The  best  marketing  is  <u>never  just  about
selling a product or service, but about taking a stand
—  showing  an  audience  why  they  should  believe  in
what you’re marketing enough to want it at any cost,
simply because they</u> <u>agree with what you’re doing.</u> 
Products  can  be  changed  or  adjusted  if  they  aren’t
functioning, but rallying points  <u>exclude the values
and meaning behind what you do.</u> Thus, marketing is
more than advertising and sales: it is  <u>sum of all the
beliefs and attitudes about a product or service.</u>

you;  it  becomes  a  rallying  point.</u>  Displaying  your
perspective  lets  prospective  (and  current)  customers
know  that  you  don’t   just  sell  your  products  or
services.  The  best  marketing  is  <u>never  just  about
selling a product or service, but about taking a stand
—  showing  an  audience  why  they  should  believe  in
what you’re marketing enough to want it at any cost,
simply because they</u> <u>agree with what you’re doing.</u> 
Products  can  be  changed  or  adjusted  if  they  aren’t
functioning, but rallying points  <u>exclude the values
and meaning behind what you do.</u> Thus, marketing is
more than advertising and sales: it is  <u>sum of all the
beliefs and attitudes about a product or service.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
If DNA were the only thing that mattered, there would
be  no  particular  reason  to  build  meaningful  social
programs to pour good experiences into children and
protect them from bad experiences. But brains require
the right kind of environment if they are to  <u>correctly
develop.</u> When the first draft of the Human Genome
Project  came  to  completion  at  the  turn  of  the
millennium,  one  of  the  great  <u>surprises  was  that
humans have only about twenty thousand genes.</u> This
number came as a surprise to biologists: given the 
<u>simplicity  of  the  brain  and  the  body,  it  had  been
assumed that hundreds of thousands of genes would
be required.</u> So how does the  <u>massively complicated
brain,  with  its  eighty‐six  billion  neurons,  get  built
from such a small recipe book?</u> The answer relies on a
clever strategy  <u>implemented by the genome: build
incompletely and let world experience refine.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
One benefit of reasons and arguments is that they can
foster  humility.  If  two  people  <u>disagree without
arguing, all they do is yell at each other.</u> No progress is
made. Both still think that they are right. In contrast, if
both  sides  give  arguments  that  articulate  reasons  for
their positions, then new possibilities  <u>open up.</u> One of
the arguments gets refuted ― that is, it is shown to fail.
In that case, the person who depended on the refuted
argument learns that he needs to  <u>stick to his view.</u>
That is one way to achieve humility ― on one side at
least.  Another  possibility  is  that  neither  argument  is
 <u>refuted.</u> Both have a degree of reason on their side.
Even  if  neither  person  involved  is  convinced  by  the
other's argument, both can still come to  <u>appreciate
the opposing view.</u> They also realize that, even if they
have some truth, they do not have the whole truth. They
can gain humility when they recognize and appreciate
the reasons against their own view.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the next. This is  <u>different from acclimation — an
individual organism’s changes in response to an altered
environment.</u> For example, if you spend the summer
outside, you may acclimate to the sunlight: your skin
will  increase  its  concentration  of  dark  pigments  that
protect  you  from  the  sun.  This  is  a  <u>temporary
change, and you won’t pass the temporary change on
to  future  generations.</u>  However,  the  capacity  to
produce skin pigments is  <u>inherited.</u> For populations
living in intensely sunny environments, individuals with
a good ability to produce skin pigments are more likely
to thrive, or to survive, than people with a poor ability
to  produce  pigments,  and  that  trait  becomes
increasingly  <u>rare in subsequent generations.</u> If you
look  around,  you  can  find  countless  examples  of
adaptation. The distinctive long neck of a giraffe, for
example,  developed  as  individuals  that  happened  to
have longer necks had an  <u>advantage in feeding on
the leaves of tall trees.</u> 
* pigment: 색소

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
On any day of the year, the tropics and the hemisphere
that  is  experiencing  its  warm  season  receive  much
more solar radiation than do the polar regions and the
colder  hemisphere.  Averaged  over  the  course  of  the
year, the tropics and latitudes up to about 40° receive
more total heat than they lose by radiation. Latitudes
above 40° receive  <u>less total heat than they lose by
radiation.</u>   This   inequality   produces   the 
<u>inevitable  conditions  for  the  operation  of  a  huge,
global‐scale engine that takes on heat in the tropics
and gives it off in the polar regions.</u> Its working fluid is
the atmosphere, especially the moisture it  <u>contains.</u>
Air is heated over the warm earth of the tropics, 
<u>contracts, rises, and flows away both northward and
southward at high altitudes, cooling as it goes.</u> It 
<u>descends  and  flows  toward  the  equator  again  from
more northerly and southerly latitudes.</u> 
*latitude: 위도

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Greenwashing involves  <u>misleading a consumer into
thinking  a  good  or  service  is  more  environmentally
friendly  than  it  really  is.</u>  Greenwashing  ranges  from
making  environmental  claims  required  by  law,  and
therefore irrelevant (CFC‐free for example), to puffery
(exaggerating  environmental  claims)  to  fraud.
Researchers have shown that claims on products are
often  too  <u>ambiguous.</u>  Some  products  are  labeled
“chemical‐free,” when the fact is everything contains
chemicals, including plants and animals. Products with
the  highest  number  of  misleading  or  unverifiable
claims  were  laundry  detergents,  household  cleaners,
and  paints.  Environmental  advocates  agree  there  is
still  a  long  way  to  go  to  <u>ensure  shoppers  are
adequately informed about the environmental impact
of the products they buy.</u> The most common reason for
greenwashing  is  to  attract  environmentally  conscious
consumers. Many consumers do not find out about the
false  claims  until  after  the  purchase.  Therefore,
greenwashing may  <u>decrease sales in the short term.</u>
However,  this  strategy  can  seriously  backfire  when
consumers find out they are being  <u>deceived.</u>
*CFC: 염화불화탄소 **fraud: 사기

switch  off,  and  when  this  happens  we  are  often

overconnected,  overwhelmed,  and  overstimulated
world.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news out
of  the  way  is  attempting  to  soften  it  or  simply  not
address it at all. This "Mum Effect" - a term coined by
psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in the
early 1970s - happens because people want to  <u>avoid
becoming the target of others' negative emotions.</u> We all
have the opportunity to lead change, yet it often requires
of us the courage to deliver bad news to our superiors.
We don't want to be the person who gets the blame for
reporting  <u>pleasant news.</u> When our survival instincts
kick in, they can  <u>override our courage until the truth
of a situation gets watered down.</u> "The Mum Effect and
the resulting filtering can have devastating effects in a
steep  <u>hierarchy,"  writes  Robert  Sutton,  an
organizational  psychologist.</u>  "What  starts  out  as  bad
news becomes happier and happier as it travels up the
ranks - because after each boss hears the news from his
or  her  subordinates,  he  or  she  makes  it  sound  a  bit
 <u>less bad before passing it up the chain.</u>"
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
Most  parents  think  that  if  our  child  would  just
“behave,”  we  could (A)  [lose  /  maintain]  our
composure as parents. The truth is that managing our
own  emotions  and  actions  is  what  allows  us  to  feel
peaceful  as  parents.  Ultimately  we  can’t  control  our
children or the obstacles they will face ―but we can
always control our own actions. Parenting isn’t about
what  our  child  does,  but  about  how  we  respond.  In
fact, most of what we call parenting doesn’t take place
between  a  parent  and  child  but  within  the  parent.
When a storm brews, a parent’s response will either
calm  it  or (B)  [provoke  /  suppress]  a  full‐scale
tsunami.   Staying   calm   enough   to   respond
constructively to all that childish behavior ― and the
stormy  emotions  behind  it  ―requires  that  we  grow,
too. If we can use those times when our buttons get
pushed to reflect, not just react, we can notice when
we lose equilibrium and steer ourselves back on track.
This inner growth is the hardest work there is, but it’s
what enables you to become a more (C)  [hostile  /
tranquil] parent, one day at a time.

(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장</u>
text:
Most  parents  think  that  if  our  child  would  just
“behave,”  we  could (A)  [lose  /  maintain]  our
composure as parents. The truth is that managing our
own  emotions  and  actions  is  what  allows  us  to  feel
peaceful  as  parents.  Ultimately  we  can’t  control  our
children or the obstacles they will face ―but we can
always control our own actions. Parenting isn’t about
what  our  child  does,  but  about  how  we  respond.  In
fact, most of what we call parenting doesn’t take place
between  a  parent  and  child  but  within  the  parent.
When a storm brews, a parent’s response will either
calm  it  or (B)  [provoke  /  suppress]  a  full‐scale
tsunami.   Staying   calm   enough   to   respond
constructively to all that childish behavior ― and the
stormy  emotions  behind  it  ―requires  that  we  grow,
too. If we can use those times when our buttons get
pushed to reflect, not just react, we can notice when
we lose equilibrium and steer ourselves back on track.
This inner growth is the hardest work there is, but it’s
what enables you to become a more (C)  [hostile  /
tranquil] parent, one day at a time.
 <u>maintain - provoke - tranquil</u> <u>lose - provoke - tranquil</u> <u>lose - provoke - hostile</u> <u>maintain - suppress - hostile</u> <u>lose - suppress - tranquil
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장</u>
options: ① <u>maintain - provoke - tranquil</u>
② <u>lose - provoke - tranquil</u>
③ <u>lose - provoke - hostile</u>
④ <u>maintain - suppress - hostile</u>

⑤ <u>lose - suppress - tranquil
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장</u>
explanation: (A) 대부분의 부모들은 그들의 자녀가 그저 “잘 행 동하면” 부모로서 침착함을 유지할 수 있다고 생각한다가 흐름상 자연스러우므로, maintain(유지하다)이 적절하다. lose는 '잃 다'라는 뜻이다. (B) 폭풍이 일어나려고 할 때, 부모의 반응은 그 것을 잠재우거나 최대치의 해일을 유발할 것이다가 흐름상 자연스 러우므로, provoke(유발하다)가 적절하다. suppress는 '억누르 다' 라는 뜻이다. (C) 그것은 당신이 하루하루 더욱 평안한 부모가 될 수 있도록 해주는 것이다가 흐름상 자연스러우므로, tranquil(평안한)이 적절하다. hostile은 '적대적인' 라는 뜻이다.

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
We  have  already  seen  that  learning  is  much  more
efficient  when  done  at  regular  intervals:  rather  than
(A)  [jamming  /  clearing] an entire lesson into one
day, we are better off spreading out the learning. The
reason  is  simple:  every  night,  our  brain (B)
[consolidates / separate] what it has learned during
the  day.  This  is  one  of  the  most  important
neuroscience discoveries of the last thirty years: sleep
is not just a period of inactivity or a garbage collection
of the waste products that the brain accumulated while
we were awake. Quite the contrary: while we sleep,
our brain remains (C)  [active  /  inactive]; it runs a
specific algorithm that replays the important events it
recorded  during  the  previous  day  and  gradually
transfers them into a more efficient compartment of
our memory.
 <u>jamming - separate - inactive</u> <u>jamming - consolidates - inactive</u> <u>clearing - consolidates - inactive</u> <u>clearing - separate - active</u> <u>jamming - consolidates - active</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
From the earliest times, healthcare services have been
recognized  to  have  two  equal  aspects,  namely  clinical
care and public healthcare. In classical Greek mythology,
the  god  of  medicine,  Asklepios,  had  two  daughters,
Hygiea  and  Panacea.  The  former  was  the  goddess  of
preventive  health  and  wellness,  or  hygiene,  and  the
latter the goddess of treatment and curing. In modern
times,  the  societal  <u>ascendancy of  medical
professionalism  has  caused  treatment  of  sick  patients</u> <u>to overshadow those preventive healthcare services
provided  by  the</u> <u>less heroic  figures  of  sanitary
engineers,  biologists,  and  governmental  public  health
officers.</u> Nevertheless, the quality of health that human
populations  enjoy  is  attributable  <u>more to  surgical
dexterity,  innovative  pharmaceutical  products,  and
bioengineered devices than to the availability of public
sanitation,  sewage  management,  and  services  which
control  the  pollution  of  the  air,  drinking  water,  urban
noise,  and  food  for  human  consumption.</u>  The  human
right  to  the  highest  attainable  standard  of  health
depends on public healthcare services  <u>no less than on
the skills and equipment of doctors and hospitals.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?(2개)
mainText:
By noticing the relation between their own actions and
resultant  external  changes,  infants  develop  self‐
efficacy,  a  sense  that  they  are  <u>agents  of  the
perceived  changes.</u>  Although  infants  can  notice  the
effect of their behavior on the physical environment, it
is in early social interactions that infants most readily
perceive the  <u>consequence of their actions.</u> People
have  perceptual  characteristics  that  virtually  assure
that  infants  will  <u>ignore  toward  them.</u>  They  have
visually  contrasting  and  moving  faces.  They  produce
sound, provide touch, and have interesting smells. In
addition, people engage with infants by exaggerating
their  facial  expressions  and  inflecting  their  voices  in
ways  that  infants  find  fascinating.  But  most
importantly, these antics are  <u>responsible to infants’
vocalizations, facial expressions, and gestures; people
vary the pace and level of their behavior in response to
infant  actions.</u>  Consequentially,  early  social 
<u>interactions provide a context where infants can easily
notice the effect of their behavior.</u>
* inflect: (음성을) 조절하다 ** antics: 익살스러운 행동

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adam  Smith  pointed  out  that  specialization,  where
each  of  us  focuses  on  one  specific  skill,  leads  to  a
general improvement of everybody’s well‐being. The
idea is simple and powerful. By specializing in just one
activity ―such as food raising, clothing production, or
home  construction  ―  each  worker  gains 
<u>expertness  over  the  particular  activity.</u>  Specialization
makes  sense,  however,  only  if  the  specialist  can
subsequently trade his or her output with the output of
specialists in other lines of activity. It would make no
sense to produce  <u>more food than a household needs
unless  there  is  a  market  outlet  to  exchange  that
excess food for clothing, shelter, and so forth.</u> At the
same  time,  without  the  ability  to  buy  food  on  the
market,  it  would  not  be  possible  to  be  a  specialist
home  builder  or  clothing  maker,  since  it  would  be
necessary to farm for one’s own survival. Thus Smith
realized that the division of labor is  <u>limited by the
extent  of  the  market,  whereas  the  extent  of  the
market is determined by the degree of specialization.</u>
In a very small market, individuals are not motivated
to  have  the  incentive  fully  commit  to  a  single
occupation  because  they  <u>possess  the  means  to
trade the surplus of what they produce beyond their
own  needs.</u>  This  surplus,  which  <u>exceeds  their
personal  consumption,  cannot  be  exchanged  for  the
products created by others that they require.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It  is  not  the  peasant's  goal  to  produce  the  highest
possible time‐averaged crop yield, averaged over many
years.  If  your  time‐averaged  yield  is  marvelously
 <u>high as a result of the combination of nine great years
and one year of crop failure, you will still starve to death
in that one year of crop failure before you can look back
to</u> <u>celebrate yourself  on  your  great  time-averaged
yield.</u>  Instead,  the  peasant's  aim  is  to  make  sure  to
produce a yield above the  <u>famine level in every single
year, even though the time-averaged yield may not be
highest.</u>  That's  why  field  scattering  <u>interrupts
agricultural risk management.</u> If you have just one big
field, no matter how good it is on the average, you will
starve  when  the  inevitable  occasional  year  arrives  in
which your one field has a low yield. But if you have
many different fields, varying  <u>separately of each other,
then in any given year some of your fields will produce
well even when your other fields are producing poorly.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
There  are  several  reasons  why  support  may  not  be
 <u>effective.</u> One possible reason is that receiving help
could  be  a blow to  self-esteem.  A  recent  study  by
Christopher  Burke  and  Jessica  Goren  at  Lehigh
University examined this possibility. According to the
threat to self-esteem model, help can be perceived as
supportive and loving, or it can be seen as threatening
if that help is interpreted as implying  <u>competence.</u>
According  to  Burke  and  Goren,  support  is  especially
likely to be seen as threatening if it is in an area that is
self-relevant or self-defining – that is, in an area where
your  own  success  and  achievement  are  especially
 <u>important.</u> Receiving help with a self-relevant task
can  make  you  feel  bad  about  yourself,  and  this  can
 <u>undermine the potential positive effects of the help.</u>
For example, if your self-concept  <u>rests, in part, on
your great cooking ability, it may be a blow to your ego
when  a  friend  helps  you  prepare  a  meal  for  guests
because  it  suggests  that  you’re  not  the  master  chef
you thought you were.</u>

⑤ <u>rests, in part, on
your great cooking ability, it may be a blow to your ego
when  a  friend  helps  you  prepare  a  meal  for  guests
because  it  suggests  that  you’re  not  the  master  chef
you thought you were.</u>
explanation: 만약 그 도움이 무능함을 암시하는 것으로 해석된다 면 위협적으로 보여질 수 있다는 문맥이 되도록 ② competence(능력)을 incompetence(무능함)으로 고쳐야 한다.

As well as making sense of events through narratives,
historians in the ancient world established the tradition
of  history  as  a  source  of  moral  lessons  and
<u>reflections.</u> The history writing of Livy or Tacitus, for
instance, was in part designed to examine the behavior
of heroes and villains, <u>mediating on the strengths
and  weaknesses  in  the  characters  of  emperors  and
generals,  providing  exemplars  for  the</u><u>virtuous  to
imitate  or  avoid.</u>  This  continues  to  be  one  of  the
functions  of  history.  French  chronicler  Jean  Froissart
said  he  had  written  his <u>accounts  of  chivalrous
knights  fighting  in  the  Hundred  Years’  War  “so  that
brave men should be</u><u>inspired thereby to follow such
examples.</u>”  Today,  historical  studies  of  Lincoln,
Churchill,  Gandhi,  or  Martin  Luther  King,  Jr.  perform
the same function.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Psychologist  Christopher  Bryan  finds  that  when  we
shift  our  emphasis  from  behavior  to  <u>character,
people evaluate choices differently.</u> His team was able
to cut cheating in half: instead of “Please don’t cheat,”
they changed the appeal to “Please don’t be a cheater.”
When you’re urged not to cheat, you can do it and still
see  an  <u>immoral  person  in  the  mirror.</u>  But  when
you’re told not to be a cheater, the act casts a shadow;
immorality is tied to your identity, making the behavior
much  <u>less  attractive.</u>  Cheating  is  an  <u>isolated
action  that  gets  evaluated  with  the  logic  of
consequence: Can I get away with it?</u> Being a cheater
evokes  a  sense  of  <u>self,  triggering  the  logic  of
appropriateness: What kind of person am I, and who
do  I  want  to  be?</u>  In  light  of  this  evidence,  Bryan
suggests  that  we  should  embrace  nouns  more
thoughtfully.  “Don’t  Drink  and  Drive”  could  be
rephrased  as:  “Don’t  Be  a  Drunk  Driver.”  The  same
thinking  can  be  applied  to  originality.  When  a  child
draws a picture, instead of calling the artwork creative,
we can say “You are creative.”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Taking  a  stand  is  important  because  you  become  a
beacon for those individuals who are your people, your
tribe,  and  your  audience.  When  you  raise  your
viewpoint  up  like  a  flag,  people  know  where  to  find
you;  it  becomes  a  rallying  point.  Displaying  your 
<u>way  of  thinking  lets</u> <u>prospective  (and  current)
customers know that you don’t just sell your products
or  services.</u>  The  best  marketing  is  never  just  about
selling a product or service, but about taking a stand
—  showing  an  audience  why  they  should  believe  in
what you’re marketing enough to want it  <u>without
any cost, simply because they agree with what you’re
doing.</u> Products  can  be  changed  or  adjusted  if  they
aren’t  <u>functioning, but rallying points</u> <u>align with
the values and meaning behind what you do.</u>
*beacon: 횃불 **rallying point: 집합 지점

explanation: 마케팅에서 입장을 취하는 것은 소비자들이 사업에 대한 의미와 가치를 믿고 따르게 하는 집합 지점의 역할을 하는 것 으로 마케팅에서 관점을 보여주는 것의 중요성을 강조하고 있는 글로 ‘단순히 청중들이 당신이 하는 것에 동의하기 때문에, 왜 그 들이 당신이 마케팅하는 것을 어떠한 비용을 지불하더라도 그것을 원할만큼 충분히 믿어야 하는지를 청중들에게 보여주는 것에 대한 것이다’는 흐름이 적절하므로 ③ without any cost(비용 없이)를 at any cost(어떤 비용을 지불하더라도)등으로 고쳐야 한다. [참 고] 고객이 당신의 브랜드에 대한 신념을 가지고 그 가치를 위해 비용을 지불할 의향이 있다는 점을 강조하는 것이 더 적절하고, without any cost(비용 없이)는 마케팅의 본질이나 고객의 참여 를 강조하는 데 적합하지 않다. (정답지) 2022년도 9월 2학년 2022년9월고2모의고사 - 3 - 진진영어

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
One benefit of reasons and arguments is that they can
foster  humility.  If  two  people  <u>disagree  without
arguing, all they do is yell at each other.</u> No progress is
made. Both still think that they are right. In contrast, if
both sides give arguments that articulate reasons for
their positions, then new possibilities  <u>open up.</u> One
of the arguments gets refuted — that is, it is shown to
fail.  In  that  case,  the  person  who  depended  on  the
refuted  argument  learns  that  he  needs  to  <u>stick
to his view.</u> That is one way to achieve humility —on
one  side  at  least.  Another  possibility  is  that  neither
argument is  <u>refuted.</u> Both have a degree of reason
on  their  side.  Even  if  neither  person  involved  is
convinced by the other’s argument, both can still come
to  <u>appreciate the opposing view.</u> They also realize
that, even if they have some truth, they do not have
the  whole  truth.  They  can  gain  humility  when  they
recognize and appreciate the reasons against their own
view.
*articulate: 분명히 말하다 **humility: 겸손

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the  next.  This  is  different  from  acclimation ― an
individual organism's changes in response to an altered
environment.  For  example,  if  you  spend  the  summer
outside, you may acclimate to the sunlight: your skin will
increase  its  concentration  of  dark  pigments  that
 <u>protect you from the sun.</u> This is a  <u>permanent
change, and you won't pass the temporary change on to
future  generations.</u>  However,  the  capacity  to  produce
skin  pigments  is  inherited.  For  populations  living  in
intensely  sunny  environments,  individuals  with  a  good
ability to produce skin pigments are more likely to thrive,
or to survive, than people with a poor ability to produce
pigments,  and  that  trait  becomes  increasingly
 <u>common in  subsequent  generations.</u>  If  you  look
around,  you  can  find  countless  examples  of
 <u>adaptation.</u> The distinctive long neck of a giraffe, for
example, developed as individuals that happened to have
longer necks had  <u>advantages in feeding on the leaves
of tall trees.</u>

explanation: 햇빛으로부터의 보호를 위해 피부가 짙은 농도의 색 소를 증가시키는 것은 순응의 예시이므로, 다음 세대로 유전되지 않는 '일시적인’ 변화이다. 따라서, ② permanent(영구적인)를 temporary(일시적인) 등으로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Greenwashing  involves  <u>fooling  a  consumer  into
thinking  a  good  or  service  is  more  environmentally
friendly  than  it  really  is.</u>  Greenwashing  ranges  from
making  environmental  claims  required  by  law,  and
therefore irrelevant (CFC‐free for example), to excess
advertisement  <u>exaggerating environmental claims to
fraud.</u> Researchers have shown that claims on products
are often too vague or misleading. Some products are
labeled “chemical‐free,” when the fact is everything
 <u>contains  chemicals,  including  plants  and  animals.</u>
Products  with  the  highest  number  of  misleading  or
unverifiable claims were laundry detergents, household
cleaners,  and  paints.  Environmental  advocates  agree
there is still a long way to go to ensure shoppers are
 <u>ignorant  about  the  environmental  impact  of  the
products  they  buy.</u>  The  most  common  reason  for
greenwashing  is  to  attract  environmentally  conscious
consumers. Many consumers do not find out about the
false  claims  until  after  the  purchase.  Therefore,
greenwashing may  <u>increase sales in the short term.</u>
However,  this  strategy  can  seriously  backfire  when
consumers find out they are being deceived.
*CFC: 염화불화탄소 **fraud: 사기

We usually take time out only when we really need to
switch  off,  and  when  this  happens  we  are  often 
<u>overtired, sick, and in need of recuperation.</u> Me time is
complicated  by  negative  associations  with  escapism,
guilt,  and  regret  as  well  as  overwhelm,  stress,  and
fatigue. All these  <u>negative connotations mean we
tend to steer clear of it.</u> Well, I am about to change
your  <u>perception of the importance of me time, to
persuade you that you should view it as</u> <u>trivial for
your health and wellbeing.</u> Take this as permission to
set aside some time for yourself! Our need for time in
which to do what we choose is increasingly  <u>urgent in
an  overconnected,  overwhelmed,  and  overstimulated
world.</u>
*recuperation: 회복

complicated  by  negative  associations  with  escapism,
guilt,  and  regret  as  well  as  overwhelm,  stress,  and
fatigue. All these  <u>negative connotations mean we
tend to steer clear of it.</u> Well, I am about to change
your  <u>perception of the importance of me time, to
persuade you that you should view it as</u> <u>trivial for
your health and wellbeing.</u> Take this as permission to
set aside some time for yourself! Our need for time in
which to do what we choose is increasingly  <u>urgent in
an  overconnected,  overwhelmed,  and  overstimulated
world.</u>
*recuperation: 회복
options: ① <u>overtired, sick, and in need of recuperation.</u>

② <u>negative connotations mean we
tend to steer clear of it.</u>

③ <u>perception of the importance of me time, to
persuade you that you should view it as</u>

④ <u>trivial for
your health and wellbeing.</u>

⑤ <u>urgent in
an  overconnected,  overwhelmed,  and  overstimulated
world.</u>
explanation: 나를 위한 시간의 중요성을 인식해야 한다고 주장하 는 글이므로, ④ trivial(사소한, 하찮은)을 '중요한, 필수적인'을 의미하는 vital, essential, important, imperative 등으로 고쳐 야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news
out of the way is attempting to soften it or simply not
address it at all. This “Mum Effect” — a term coined by
psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in the
early 1970s — happens because people want to avoid
becoming the target of others’  <u>negative emotions.</u>
We all have the opportunity to lead change, yet it often
requires of us the  <u>courage to deliver bad news to
our  superiors.</u>  We  don’t  want  to  be  the  <u>innocent
messenger  who  falls  before  a  firing  line.</u>  When  our
survival  instincts  kick  in,  they  can  <u>inspire  our
courage  until  the  truth  of  a  situation  gets  watered
down.</u> “The Mum Effect and the resulting filtering can
have devastating effects in a steep hierarchy,” writes
Robert  Sutton,  an  organizational  psychologist.  “What
starts out as bad news becomes happier and happier
as it travels up the ranks ― because after each boss
hears the news from his or her subordinates, he or she
makes it sound a bit  <u>less bad before passing it up
the chain.</u>”
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

Most parents think that if our child would just "behave,"
we  could  stay  calm  as  parents.  The  truth  is  that
managing our own emotions and actions is what allows
us to feel peaceful as parents. Ultimately we can't control
our children or the obstacles they will face - but we can
always  control  our  own  actions.  Parenting  isn't  about
what our child does, but about how we     (A)   . In
fact, most of what we call parenting doesn't take place
between a parent and child but within the parent. When
a storm brews, a parent's response will either calm it or
trigger  a  full‐scale  tsunami.  Staying  calm  enough  to
respond constructively to all that childish behavior - and
the stormy emotions behind it - requires that we grow,
too. If we can use those times when our buttons get
pushed  to     (B)   ,  not  just     (C)   ,  we  can
notice when we lose equilibrium and steer ourselves back
on track. This inner growth is the hardest work there is,
but it's what enables you to become a more peaceful
parent, one day at a time.

We  have  already  seen  that  learning  is  much  more
efficient when done at regular  <u>intervals: rather than
cramming an entire lesson into one day, we are better off
spreading out the learning.</u> The reason is simple: every
night, our brain  <u>integrates what it has learned during
the day.</u> This is one of the most important neuroscience
discoveries of the last thirty years: sleep is not just a
 <u>phase of inactivity or a garbage collection of the waste
products  that  the  brain  accumulated  while  we  were
awake.</u>  Quite  the  contrary:  while  we  sleep.  our  brain
remains active: it  <u>contends a specific algorithm that
replays  the  important  events  it  recorded  during  the
previous day and gradually</u> <u>relocates them into a more
efficient compartment of our memory.</u>

From the earliest times, healthcare services have been
recognized to have two  <u>equivalent aspects, namely
clinical  care  and  public  healthcare.</u>  In  classical  Greek
mythology,  the  god  of  medicine,  Asklepios,  had  two
daughters,  Hygiea  and  Panacea.  The  former  was  the
goddess  of  <u>preventive health  and  wellness,  or
hygiene,  and  the  latter  the  goddess  of  treatment  and
curing.</u>  In  modern  times,  the  societal  ascendancy  of
medical  professionalism  has  caused  treatment  of  sick
patients to  <u>overestimate those preventive healthcare
services provided by the less heroic figures of sanitary
engineers,  biologists,  and  governmental  public  health
officers.</u> Nevertheless, the quality of health that human
populations enjoy is due  <u>more to the availability of
public  sanitation,  sewage  management,  and  services
which  control  the  pollution  of  the  air,  drinking  water,
urban noise, and food for human consumption than to
surgical  dexterity,  innovative  pharmaceutical  products,
and  bioengineered  devices.</u>  The  human  right  to  the
highest  attainable  standard  of  health  <u>depends on
public healthcare services no less than on the skills and
equipment of doctors and hospitals.</u>

By noticing the relation between their own actions and
resultant external changes, infants develop self-efficacy,
a sense that they are agents of the perceived changes.
Although infants can notice the effect of their behavior on
the  physical  environmental,  it  is  in  early  social
interactions that infants most readily  <u>recognize the
consequence  of  their  actions.</u>  People  have  perceptual
characteristics that virtually  <u>convince that infants will
orient toward them.</u> They have visually contrasting and
moving faces. They produce sound, provide touch, and
have interesting smells. In addition, people engage with
infants  by  exaggerating  their  facial  expressions  and
inflecting  their  voices  in  ways  that  infants  find
 <u>appealing.</u>  But  most  importantly,  these  antics  are
responsive  to  infants’  vocalizations,  facial  expressions,
and gestures; people  <u>adjust the pace and level of their
behavior in response to infant actions.</u> Consequentially,
early social interactions provide a context where infants
can  <u>insufficiently notice the effect of their behavior.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adam  Smith  pointed  out  that  specialization,  where
each  of  us  focuses  on  one  specific  skill,  leads  to  a
general improvement of everybody’s well‐being. The
idea is simple and powerful. By specializing in just one
activity ―such as food raising, clothing production, or
home  construction  ―  each  worker  <u>gains  mastery
over  the  particular  activity.</u>  Specialization  makes
sense,  however,  <u>only  if  the  specialist  can
subsequently trade his or her output with the output of
specialists in other lines of activity.</u> It would make no
sense to produce more food than a household needs 
<u>if there is a market outlet to exchange that excess food
for clothing, shelter, and so forth.</u> At the same time,
without the ability to buy food on the market, it would
not  be  possible  to  be  a  specialist  home  builder  or
clothing maker,  <u>since it would be necessary to farm
for  one’s  own  survival.</u>  Thus  Smith  realized  that  the
division of labor is limited by the extent of the market,
 <u>whereas the extent of the market is determined by
the degree of specialization.</u>

mainText:
It  is  not  the  peasant’s  goal  to  produce  the  highest
possible  time‐averaged  crop  yield,  averaged  over
many  years.  If  your  time‐averaged  yield  is
marvelously  <u>abundant as a result of the combination
of nine great years and one year of crop failure, you
will still starve to death in that one year of crop failure
before you can look back to congratulate yourself on
your  great  time‐averaged  yield.</u>  Instead,  the
peasant’s aim is to make sure not to produce a yield 
<u>below the starvation level in every single year, even
though the time‐averaged yield may not be highest.</u>
That’s why field scattering may  <u>make sense.</u> If you
have just one big field, no matter how good it is on the
average,  you  will  starve  when  the  <u>inevitable
occasional year arrives in which your one field has a
low yield.</u> But if you have many different fields, varying
independently  of  each  other,  then  in  any  given  year
some of your fields will produce well even when your
other fields are producing  <u>adequately.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

recent study by Christopher Burke and Jessica Goren
at  Lehigh  University (B)  [scrambled  /  examined]
this possibility. According to the threat to self‐esteem
model, help can be perceived as supportive and loving,
or  it  can  be  seen  as  threatening  if  that  help  is
interpreted  as  implying  incompetence.  According  to
Burke  and  Goren,  support  is  especially  likely  to  be
seen  as  threatening  if  it  is  in  an  area  that  is  self‐
relevant or self‐defining — that is, in an area where
your  own  success  and  achievement  are  especially
important.  Receiving  help  with  a  self‐relevant  task
can  make  you  feel  bad  about  yourself,  and  this  can
undermine  the  potential  positive  effects  of  the  help.

/ blow] to your ego when a friend helps you prepare
a meal for guests because it suggests that you’re not

of  the  functions  of  history.  French  chronicler  Jean
Froissart said he had written his accounts of chivalrous
knights  fighting  in  the  Hundred  Years’  War  “so  that
brave men should be inspired thereby to follow such
examples.”  Today,  historical  studies  of  Lincoln,
Churchill,  Gandhi,  or  Martin  Luther  King,  Jr.  perform
the same function.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Psychologist Christopher Bryan finds that when we shift
our  emphasis  from  behavior  to  <u>character,  people
evaluate  choices  differently.</u>  His  team  was  able  to  cut
cheating  in  half:  instead  of  “Please  don’t  cheat,”  they
changed the appeal to “Please don’t be a cheater.” When
you’re urged not to cheat, you can do it and still see an
ethical person in the mirror. But when you’re told not to
be a cheater, the act casts a shadow; immorality is tied
to  your  <u>identity,  making  the  behavior  much  less
attractive.</u>  Cheating  is  an  isolated  action  that  gets
evaluated with the logic of  <u>consequence: Can I get
away with it?</u> Being a cheater evokes a sense of self,
triggering the logic of  <u>appropriateness: What kind of
person am I, and who do I want to be?</u> In light of this
evidence,  Bryan  suggests  that  we  should  embrace
 <u>verbs more thoughtfully.</u> “Don’t Drink and Drive” could
be rephrased as: “Don’t Be a Drunk Driver.” The same
thinking can be applied to originality. When a child draws
a picture, instead of calling the artwork creative, we can
say “You are creative.”

evaluate  choices  differently.</u>

② <u>identity,  making  the  behavior  much  less
attractive.</u>

③ <u>consequence: Can I get

⑤ <u>verbs more thoughtfully.</u>

One benefit of reasons and arguments is that they can
 <u>foster humility.</u>  If  two  people  disagree  without
arguing, all they do is yell at each other. No progress is
made. Both still think that they are right. In contrast, if
both  sides  give  arguments  that  articulate  reasons  for
their positions, then new possibilities open up. One of the
arguments gets refuted — that is, it is shown to  <u>fail.</u>
In that case, the person who depended on the refuted
argument learns that he needs to  <u>stick to his view
What is one way to achieve humility — on one side at
least.</u>  Another  possibility  is  that  neither  argument  is
refuted. Both have a degree of reason on their side. Even
if  neither  person  involved  is  convinced  by  the  other's
argument  both  can  still  come  to  <u>appreciate the
opposing view.</u> They also realize that, even if they have
some truth, they do not have the  <u>whole truth.</u> They
can gain humility when they recognize and appreciate
the reasons against their own view.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the  next.  This  is  different  from  acclimation  —  an
individual  organism’s  changes  in  response  to  an 
<u>altered  environment.</u>  For  example,  if  you  spend  the
summer outside, you may acclimate to the sunlight:
your  skin  will  increase  its  concentration  of  dark
pigments that protect you from the sun. This is a 
<u>temporary change, and you won’t pass the momentary
change  on  to  future  generations.</u>  However,  the 
<u>capability  to  produce  skin  pigments  is  inherited.</u>  For
populations  living  in  intensely  sunny  environments,
individuals  with  a  good  ability  to  produce  skin
pigments are more likely to  <u>survive, than people
with a poor ability to produce pigments, and that trait
becomes  increasingly</u> <u>rare  in  subsequent
generations.</u> If you look around, you can find countless
examples of adaptation. The distinctive long neck of a
giraffe,  for  example,  developed  as  individuals  that
happened to have longer necks had an advantage in
feeding on the leaves of tall trees. 
* pigment: 색소
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

Greenwashing  involves  misleading  a  consumer  into
thinking  a  good  or  service  is  more  environmentally
friendly  than  it  really  is.  Greenwashing  ranges  from
making  environmental  claims  required  by  law,  and
therefore irrelevant (CFC‐free for example), to puffery
(exaggerating  environmental  claims)  to  fraud.
Researchers have shown that claims on products are
often  too  vague  or  misleading.  Some  products  are
labeled “chemical‐free,” when the fact is everything
(A)   [includes   /   excludes]  chemicals,  including
plants and animals. Products with the highest number
of  misleading  or  unverifiable  claims  were  laundry
detergents,   household   cleaners,   and   paints.
Environmental advocates agree there is still a long way
to  go  to (B)  [ignore  /  ensure]  shoppers  are
adequately informed about the environmental impact
of the products they buy. The most common reason for
greenwashing  is  to (C)    [attract    /    expel]
environmentally   conscious   consumers.   Many
consumers do not find out about the false claims until
after  the  purchase.  Therefore,  greenwashing  may
increase sales in the short term. However, this strategy
can seriously backfire when consumers find out they
are being deceived.

explanation: (A) 그린워싱은 환경적 주장을 과장하는 과대 광고 와 사기를 포함한다는 앞 내용과, "화학물질 없음"이라고 표기되 어 있는 제품을 사례로 제시하면서 현혹적이고 확인할 수 없는 주 장이라고 말하는 점 등을 통해, 실제로 화학물질이 들어있으면서 도 없다고 표기한다는 흐름이 자연스러우므로, includes가 적절하 다. exclude: 배제하다 (B) 소비자들은 구매를 완료하고 나서야 거짓 주장임을 알아차린다고 했으므로, 소비자들이 구매하는 제품 의 환경적 영향력에 대하여 적절하게 정보를 제공받는 것을 '확실 히 하기 위해서' 여전히 갈길이 멀다고 생각한다는 흐름이 자연스 럽다. 따라서, ensure(확실하게 하다)가 알맞다. ignore: 무시하 다 (C) 그린워싱의 가장 흔한 이유는 환경적으로 의식있는 소비자 들을 유인하는 것이므로, attract가 문맥에 맞는 낱말이다. expel: 내쫓다
sourceLabel: 출처│2022년 9월 고2 모의고사 어휘 B세트 no63

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
We usually take time out only when we really need to
switch (A) [off / on], and when this happens we are
often overtired, sick, and in need of recuperation. Me
time  is  complicated  by (B)  [positive  /  negative]
associations with escapism, guilt, and regret as well as
overwhelm,  stress,  and  fatigue.  All  these  negative
connotations mean we tend to steer clear of it. Well, I
am about to change your perception of the importance
of me time, to persuade you that you should view it as
vital for your health and wellbeing. Take this as (C)
[permission  /  prohibition] to set aside some time
for yourself! Our need for time in which to do what we
choose  is  increasingly  urgent  in  an  overconnected,
overwhelmed, and overstimulated world.
*recuperation: 회복
 <u>off - negative - prohibition</u> <u>on - positive - permission</u> <u>on - negative - prohibition</u> <u>off - negative - permission</u> <u>off - positive - prohibition</u>
