question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps  <u>worse than attempting to get the bad news
out of the way is attempting to soften it or simply not
address it at all.</u> This “Mum Effect” – a term coined by
psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in the
early 1970s – happens because people want to  <u>avoid
becoming the target of others’ negative emotions.</u> We all
have the opportunity to lead change, yet it often requires
of us the courage to deliver bad news to our superiors.
We don’t want to be the innocent messenger who falls
before a firing line. When our survival instincts kick in,
they can  <u>prioritize our courage until the truth of a
situation gets watered down.</u> “The Mum Effect and the
resulting filtering can have  <u>devastating effects in a
steep hierarchy,” writes Robert Sutton, an organizational
psychologist.</u>  “What  starts  out  as  bad  news  becomes
happier and happier as it travels up the ranks – because
after  each  boss  hears  the  news  from  his  or  her
subordinates, he or she makes it sound a bit  <u>less bad
before passing it up the chain.</u>”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Most  parents  think  that  if  our  child  would  just
“behave,” we could stay calm as parents. The truth is
that managing our own emotions and actions is what
allows us to feel  <u>peaceful as parents.</u> Ultimately we
can’t control our children or the obstacles they will face
―but we can always control our own actions. Parenting
isn’t about what our child does, but about how we 
<u>respond.</u>  In  fact,  most  of  what  we  call  parenting
doesn’t  take  place  between  a  parent  and  child  but
within  the  parent.  When  a  storm  brews,  a  parent’s
response will either calm it or  <u>trigger a full‐scale
tsunami.</u>   Staying   calm   enough   to   respond
constructively to all that childish behavior ― and the
stormy  emotions  behind  it  ―requires  that  we  grow,
too. If we can use those times when our buttons get
pushed to reflect, not just react, we can notice when
we  <u>gain  equilibrium  and  steer  ourselves  back  on
track.</u> This  <u>inner growth is the hardest work there is,
but it’s what enables you to become a more peaceful
parent, one day at a time.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We  have  already  seen  that  learning  is  much  more
efficient  when  done  at  regular  intervals:  rather  than
cramming an entire lesson into one day, we are better
off  <u>distributing  out the  learning.</u>  The  reason  is
simple: every night, our brain  <u>eliminates what it has
learned  during  the  day.</u>  This  is  one  of  the  most
important  neuroscience  discoveries  of  the  last  thirty
years:  sleep  is  not  just  a  period  of  inactivity  or  a
garbage collection of the waste products that the brain
 <u>accumulated while  we  were  awake.</u>  Quite  the
contrary: while we sleep, our brain remains highly 
<u>active;  it  runs  a  specific  algorithm  that  replays  the
important events it recorded during the previous day
and  gradually  transfers  them  into  a  more  efficient
compartment  of  our  memory.</u>  Therefore,  sleep
prevents  <u>forgetting.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
From the earliest times, healthcare services have been
recognized to have two equal aspects, namely clinical
care  and  public  healthcare.  In  classical  Greek
mythology,  the  god  of  medicine,  Asklepios,  had  two
daughters, Hygiea and Panacea. The former was the
goddess  of  <u>precautionary  health  and  wellness,  or
hygiene, and the latter the goddess of treatment and
curing.</u> In modern times, the societal  <u>inferiority of
medical professionalism has caused treatment of sick
patients   to   overshadow   those   preventive
healthcare  services  provided  by  the</u> <u>less  heroic
figures  of  sanitary  engineers,  biologists,  and
governmental public health officers.</u> Nevertheless, the
quality of health that human populations enjoy is 
<u>attributable    less    to    surgical    dexterity,
innovative pharmaceutical products, and bioengineered
devices  than  to  the  availability  of  public  sanitation,
sewage management, and services which control the
pollution of the air, drinking water, urban noise, and
food for human consumption.</u> The human right to the
highest  attainable  standard  of  health  depends  on 
<u>public  healthcare  services  no  less  than  on  the  skills
and equipment of doctors and hospitals.</u>  
*ascendancy: 우세 **dexterity: 기민함

mainText:
By noticing the relation between their own actions and
 <u>subsequent external changes, infants develop self‐
efficacy, a sense that they are agents of the perceived
changes.</u> Although infants can notice the effect of their
behavior  on  the  physical  environment,  it  is  in  early
social  interactions  that  infants  most  readily  perceive
the  <u>result of their actions.</u> People have perceptual
characteristics that virtually assure that infants will be
 <u>directed  toward  them.</u>  They  have  visually
contrasting  and  moving  faces.  They  produce  sound,
provide touch, and have interesting smells. In addition,
people engage with infants by exaggerating their facial
expressions  and  inflecting  their  voices  in  ways  that
infants  find  fascinating.  But  most  importantly,  these
antics are  <u>stimulating infants’ vocalizations, facial
expressions, and gestures; people vary the pace and
level  of  their  behavior  in  response  to  infant  actions.</u>
Consequentially, early social interactions provide a 
<u>context where infants can easily notice the effect of
their behavior.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 ①~⑤ 중 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adam Smith pointed out that specialization, where each
of  us  focuses  on  one  specific  skill,  leads  to  a  general
improvement  of  everybody's  well‐being.  The  idea  is
simple and powerful. By specializing in just one activity -
such  as  food  raising,  clothing  production,  or  home
construction - each worker gains mastery over  <u>various
activities.</u>  Specialization  makes  sense,  however,  only  if
the specialist can subsequently trade his or her output
with the output of specialists in other lines of activity. It
would make no sense to  <u>produce more food than a
household  needs  unless  there  is  a  market  outlet  to</u> <u>exchange that scarce food for clothing, shelter, and so
forth.</u> At the same time, without the ability to buy food
on the market, it would not be possible to be a specialist
home  builder  or  clothing  maker,  since  it  would  be
 <u>necessary to farm for one's own survival.</u> Thus Smith
realized that the  <u>division of labor is limited by the
extent of the market, whereas the extent of the market
is determined by the degree of specialization.</u>

realized that the  <u>division of labor is limited by the
extent of the market, whereas the extent of the market
is determined by the degree of specialization.</u>

activities.</u>

forth.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It  is  not  the  peasant’s  goal  to  produce  the  highest
possible  time‐averaged  crop  yield,  averaged  over
many  years.  If  your  time‐averaged  yield  is
marvelously  <u>high as a result of the combination of
nine great years and one year of crop failure, you will
still  starve  to  death  in  that  one  year  of  crop  failure
before you can look back to congratulate yourself on
your  great  time‐averaged  yield.</u>  Instead,  the
peasant’s aim is to make sure to produce a yield 
<u>above the starvation level in every single year, even
though the time‐averaged yield may not be highest.</u>
That’s why field  <u>dispersion may make sense.</u> If you
have just one big field, no matter how good it is on the
average, you will starve when the inevitable occasional
year arrives in which your one field has a  <u>low yield.</u>
But  if  you  have  many  different  fields,  varying 
<u>dependently  of  each  other,  then  in  any  given  year
some of your fields will produce well even when your
other fields are producing poorly.</u>

There  are  several  reasons  why  support  may  not  be
 <u>effective.</u> One possibility is that receiving help could be a
blow self-esteem. A recent study by Christopher Burke and
Jessica Goren at Lehigh University examined this Possibility.
According to the threat to self-esteem model, help can be
perceived as supportive and loving, or it can be seen as
threatening  if  that  help  is  interpreted  as  implying
 <u>incompetence.</u> According to Burke and Goren, support is
especially likely to be seen as threatening if it is in an area
that is  <u>self-defining — that is, in an area where your own
success  and  achievement  are  especially  important.</u>
Receiving help with a self-relevant task can make you feel
bad about yourself, and this can  <u>enhance the potential
positive  effects  of  the  help.</u>  For  example,  if  your  self-
concept  <u>rests, in part, on your great cooking ability, it
may be a blow to your ego when a friend helps you prepare
a meal for guests because it suggests that you're not the
master chef you thought you were.</u>

question: 은?
mainText:
One benefit of reasons and arguments is that they can
foster humility.  <u>If two people agree without arguing,
all they do is yell at each other.</u> No progress is made. 
 <u>Neither of them still think they are wrong.</u> In contrast,
if both sides give arguments that articulate reasons for
their positions, then new possibilities open up. One of the
arguments gets refuted - that is, it is shown to fail. In
that  case,  <u>the  person  who  relied  on  the  refuted
argument finds it necessary to change his point of view.</u>
That is one way to achieve humility - on one side at
least. Another possibility is that  <u>neither argument is
refuted.</u>  Both  have  a  degree  of  reason  on  their  side.
(A) 당사자 중 어느 누구도 상대방의 주장에 설득되지 않더라
도, both can still come to appreciate the opposing view.
They  also  realize  that,  even  if  they  have  some
truth,  <u>they do not have the whole truth.</u> They can gain
humility when they recognize and appreciate the reasons
against their own view.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the  next.  This  is  different  from  acclimation  —  an
individual organism’s changes in response to an altered
environment. For example, if you spend the summer
outside, you may acclimate to the sunlight: your skin
will  <u>heighten its concentration of dark pigments that
protect you from the sun.</u> This is a temporary change,
and you won’t pass the  <u>temporary change on to
future generations.</u> However, the capacity to produce
skin pigments is  <u>inherited.</u> For populations living in
intensely sunny environments, individuals with a good
ability  to  produce  skin  pigments  are  more  likely  to
thrive, or to survive, than people with a poor ability to
produce pigments, and that trait becomes increasingly
 <u>common  in  subsequent  generations.</u>  If  you  look
around, you can find countless examples of adaptation.
The  distinctive  long  neck  of  a  giraffe,  for  example,
developed as individuals that happened to have longer
necks had a  <u>disadvantage in feeding on the leaves
of tall trees.</u> 
* pigment: 색소

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Greenwashing  involves  misleading  a  consumer  into
thinking  a  good  or  service  is  more  environmentally
friendly  than  it  really  is.  Greenwashing  ranges  from
making  environmental  claims  required  by  law,  and
therefore irrelevant (CFC‐free for example), to puffery
(exaggerating  environmental  claims)  to  fraud.
Researchers have shown that claims on products are
often too  <u>indefinite or misleading.</u> Some products
are  labeled  “chemical‐free,”  when  the  fact  is
everything  contains  chemicals,  including  plants  and
animals.  Products  with  the  <u>highest  number  of
misleading  or  unverifiable  claims  were  laundry
detergents,   household   cleaners,   and   paints.</u>
Environmental  <u>advocates agree there is still a long
way to go to ensure shoppers are adequately informed
about the environmental impact of the products they
buy.</u> The most common reason for greenwashing is to
 <u>draw environmentally conscious consumers.</u> Many
consumers do not find out about the false claims until
after  the  purchase.  Therefore,  greenwashing  may 
<u>decrease  sales  in  the  short  term.</u>  However,  this
strategy  can  seriously  backfire  when  consumers  find
out they are being deceived.
* CFC: 염화불화탄소 ** fraud: 사기

 <u>complicated by negative associations with escapism,

overstimulated world.</u>

mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news
out of the way is attempting to soften it or simply not
 <u>address it at all.</u> This “Mum Effect” — a term coined
by psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in
the early 1970s — happens because people want to
avoid  becoming  the  target  of  others’  negative
emotions. We all have the opportunity to lead change,
 <u>yet it often requires of us the courage to deliver bad
news  to  our  superiors.</u>  We  don’t  want  to  be  the 
<u>innocent  messenger  who  falls  before  a  firing  line.</u>
When  our  survival  instincts  kick  in,  they  can 
<u>override our courage until the truth of a situation gets
watered  down.</u>  “The  Mum  Effect  and  the  resulting
filtering  can  have  devastating  effects  in  a  steep
hierarchy,”  writes  Robert  Sutton,  an  organizational
psychologist. “What starts out as bad news becomes
happier  and  happier  as  it  travels  up  the  ranks  ―
because after each boss hears the news from his or
her subordinates, he or she makes it sound a bit 
<u>worse before passing it up the chain.</u>”

④ <u>override our courage until the truth of a situation gets
watered  down.</u>
⑤ <u>worse before passing it up the chain.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Most  parents  think  that  if  our  child  would  just
“behave,” we could stay calm as parents. The truth is
that managing our own emotions and actions is what
allows us to feel  <u>peaceful as parents.</u> Ultimately we
can’t control our children or the obstacles they will face
―  but  we  can  always  control  our  own  actions.
Parenting isn’t about what our child does, but about 
<u>how  we  respond.</u>  In  fact,  most  of  what  we  call
parenting  doesn’t  take  place  between  a  parent  and
child  but  within  the  parent.  When  a  storm  brews,  a
parent’s response will either calm it or trigger a full-
scale  tsunami.  Staying  calm  enough  to  respond
constructively to all that childish behavior ― and the 
<u>stormy emotions behind it ― requires that we grow,
too.</u> If we can use those times when our buttons get
pushed to reflect, not just react, we can notice when
we  lose  <u>equilibrium  and  steer  ourselves  back  on
track.</u> This inner  <u>banquet is the hardest work there
is,  but  it’s  what  enables  you  to  become  a  more
peaceful parent, one day at a time.</u>

mainText:
We  have  already  seen  that  learning  is  much  more
efficient when done at  <u>regular intervals: rather than
cramming an entire lesson into one day, we are better off</u> <u>spreading out  the  learning.</u>  The  reason  is  simple:
every night, 우리의 뇌는 그날 동안 학습한 것을 통합 정리한
다. This  is  one  of  the  most  important  neuroscience
discoveries of the last thirty years: sleep is not just a
period of  <u>activity or a garbage collection of the waste
products  that  the  brain  accumulated  while  we  were
awake.</u> Quite the  <u>opposite: while we sleep, our brain
remains active; it runs a specific algorithm that replays
the important events it recorded during the previous day
and  gradually</u> <u>carries them  into  a  more  efficient
compartment of our memory.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
There  are  several  reasons  why  support  may  not 
<u>work.</u> One possible reason is that receiving help could
be  a  <u>blow  to  self‐esteem.</u>  A  recent  study  by
Christopher  Burke  and  Jessica  Goren  at  Lehigh
University  examined  this  possibility.  According
to the  <u>menace to self‐esteem model, help can be
perceived as supportive and loving, or it can be seen
as threatening if that help is interpreted as implying
incompetence.</u> According to Burke and Goren, support
is especially  <u>unlikely to be seen as threatening if it is
in an area that is self‐relevant or self‐defining — that
is,  in  an  area  where  your  own  success  and
achievement are especially important.</u> Receiving help
with a self‐relevant task can make you feel bad about
yourself, and this can  <u>impair the potential positive
effects of the help.</u> For example, if your self‐concept
rests, in part, on your great cooking ability, it may be a
blow to your ego when a friend helps you prepare a
meal for guests because it suggests that you’re not the
master chef you thought you were.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Christopher  Bryan  studies  persuasion  and  influence
with an emphasis on how subtle differences in framing
can  shape  people’s  understanding  of  a  behavior  or
decision and influence their behavior choices. He finds
that  when  we  shift  our  emphasis  from  behavior  to
character, people evaluate choices  <u>differently.</u> His
team  was  able  to  cut  cheating  in  half:  instead  of
“Please  don’t  cheat,”  they  changed  the  appeal  to
“Please don’t be a cheater.” When you’re urged not to
cheat, you can do it and still see an ethical person in
the mirror. But when you’re told not to be a cheater,
the  act  casts  a  shadow;  immorality  is  tied  to  your
identity,  making  the  behavior  more  <u>attractive.</u>
Cheating is an isolated action that gets evaluated with
the  logic  of  consequence:  Can  I  get  away  with  it?
Being a cheater evokes a sense of self, triggering the
logic of  <u>correctness: What kind of person am I, and
who do I want to be?</u> People were less likely to cheat
when  a  subtle  change  in  phrasing  framed  such
behavior  as  diagnostic  of  an  <u>undesirable identity.</u>
These  results  demonstrate  the  power  of  a  subtle
linguistic  difference  to  prevent  even  private 
<u>immoral behavior  by  invoking  people’s  desire  to
maintain a self-image as good and honest.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
One benefit of reasons and arguments is that they can
foster humility. If two people disagree without arguing,
all they do is yell at each other. No  <u>breakthrough is
made.</u> Both still think that they are right. In contrast, if
both sides give arguments that articulate reasons for
their positions, then new possibilities open up. One of
the arguments gets refuted — that is, it is shown to
 <u>fail to persuade the other.</u> In that case, the person
who depended on the refuted argument learns that he
needs  to  <u>stick  to  his  view.</u>  That  is  one  way  to
achieve  humility  —  on  one  side  at  least.  Another
possibility  is  that  neither  argument  is  refuted.  Both
have a degree of reason on their side. Even if neither
person involved is convinced by the other’s argument,
both can still come to  <u>acknowledge the opposing
view.</u> They also realize that, even if they have some
truth,  they  do  not  have  the  whole  truth.  They  can
 <u>achieve  humility  when  they  recognize  and
appreciate the reasons against their own view.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the  next.  This  is  different  from  acclimation  —  an
individual  organism’s  changes  in  response  to  a 
<u>modified environment.</u> For example, if you spend the
summer outside, you may acclimate to the sunlight:
your  skin  will  increase  its  <u>concentration of  dark
pigments that protect you from the sun.</u> This is a 
<u>impermanent change,  and  you  won’t  pass  the
temporary change on to future generations.</u> However,
the capacity to produce skin pigments is  <u>succeeded.</u>
For populations living in intensely sunny environments,
individuals  with  a  good  ability  to  produce  skin
pigments are more likely to thrive, or to survive, than
people with a poor ability to produce pigments, and
that  trait  becomes  increasingly  common  in 
<u>preceding generations.</u>  If  you  look  around,  you  can
find countless examples of adaptation. The distinctive
long  neck  of  a  giraffe,  for  example,  developed  as
individuals that happened to have longer necks had an
advantage in feeding on the leaves of tall trees. 
* pigment: 색소

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Greenwashing  involves  misleading  a  consumer  into
thinking  a  good  or  service  is  more  environmentally
friendly  than  it  really  is.  Greenwashing  ranges  from
making  environmental  claims  required  by  law,  and
therefore  irrelevant  (CFC-free  for  example),  to  puffery
(exaggerating   environmental   claims)   to   fraud.
Researchers  have  shown  that  claims  on  products  are
often  too  vague  or  misleading.  Some  products  are
labeled  "chemical-free,"  when  the  fact  is  everything
contains  chemicals,  including  plants  and  animals.
Products  with  the  highest  number  of  <u>unverifiable
claims were laundry detergents, household cleaners, and
paints.</u>  Environmental  advocates  agree  there  is  still  a
long  way  to  go  to  ensure  shoppers  are  <u>falsely
informed about the environmental impact of the products
they buy.</u> The most common reason for greenwashing is
to attract environmentally  <u>conscious consumers.</u> Many
consumers do not find out about the false claims until
after  the  purchase.  Therefore,  greenwashing  may
increase  sales  in  the  <u>short term.</u>  However,  this
strategy can seriously backfire when consumers find out
they are being  <u>deceived.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

increase  sales  in  the  <u>short term.</u>  However,  this
strategy can seriously backfire when consumers find out
they are being  <u>deceived.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장
options:
① <u>unverifiable
claims were laundry detergents, household cleaners, and
paints.</u>

② <u>falsely
informed about the environmental impact of the products
they buy.</u>
③ <u>conscious consumers.</u>
④ <u>short term.</u>
⑤ <u>deceived.</u>
explanation: 소비자들이 그린워싱에 현혹되어 제품을 구매하게 되자, 환경 옹호자들은 소비자들이 그들이 구매하는 제품의 환경 적 영향력에 대하여 '적절하게' 정보를 제공받는 것을 확실하게 하 기 위해서는 여전히 갈 길이 멀다는 점에 동의한다는 맥락이 자연 스러우므로 ② falsely(거짓으로) → adequately(적절하게) 등으 로 고쳐야 한다.

We usually take time out only when we really need to
switch  off,  and  when  this  happens  we  are  often
overtired, sick, and in need of recuperation. Me time is
complicated  by (A)    [negative    /    positive]
associations with escapism, guilt, and regret as well as
overwhelm,  stress,  and  fatigue.  All  these  negative
connotations mean we tend to steer clear of it. Well, I
am  about  to  change  your (B)  [prescription  /
perception]  of  the  importance  of  me  time,  to
persuade you that you should view it as vital for your
health and wellbeing. Take this as (C) [permission /
prohibition] to set aside some time for yourself! Our
need  for  time  in  which  to  do  what  we  choose  is
increasingly urgent in an overconnected, overwhelmed,
and overstimulated world.

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news
out of the way is attempting to soften it or simply not
address it at all. This “Mum Effect” — a term coined by
psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in the
early 1970s — happens because people want to avoid
becoming  the  target  of  others’ (A)  [negative  /
positive] emotions.  We  all  have  the  opportunity  to
lead change, yet it often requires of us the courage to
deliver bad news to our superiors. We don’t want to be
the innocent messenger who falls before a firing line.
When our survival instincts kick in, they can make us
(B)  [lose  /  gather] our courage until the truth of a
situation gets watered down. “The Mum Effect and the
resulting  filtering  can  have  devastating  effects  in  a
steep   hierarchy,”   writes   Robert   Sutton,   an
organizational  psychologist.  “What  starts  out  as  bad
news becomes happier and happier as it travels up the
ranks ― because after each boss hears the news from
his or her subordinates, he or she makes it sound a bit
(C) [better / worse] before passing it up the chain.”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Most  parents  think  that  if  our  child  would  just
“behave,” we could <u>at ease as parents.</u> The truth is
that managing our own emotions and actions is what
allows  us  to  feel  peaceful  as  parents.  Ultimately  we
can’t control our children or the obstacles they will face
―but we can always control our own actions. <u>Child
rearing isn’t about what our child does, but about how
we respond.</u> In fact, most of what we call parenting
doesn’t  take  place  between  a  parent  and  child  but
within  the  parent.  When  a  storm  brews,  a  parent’s
response  will  either  calm  it  or  trigger  a  full‐scale
tsunami.   Staying   calm   enough   to   respond
<u>destructively to all that childish behavior ― and the
stormy  emotions  behind  it  ―requires  that  we  grow,
too.</u> If we can use those times when our buttons get
pushed to <u>contemplate, not just react, we can notice
when we lose equilibrium and steer ourselves back on
track.</u> This <u>enhancement of inner self is the hardest
work there is, but it’s what enables you to become a
more peaceful parent, one day at a time.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
There  are  several  reasons  why  support  may  not  be
 <u>effective.</u> One possible reason is that receiving help
could be a damage to self-esteem. A recent study by
Christopher Burke and Jessica Goren at Lehigh University
examined this possibility. According to the threat to self-
esteem model, help can be perceived as supportive and
loving, or it can be seen as threatening if that help is
interpreted  as  implying  <u>competence.</u>  According  to
Burke and Goren, support is especially likely to be seen
as threatening if it is in an area that is self-relevant or
self-defining – that is, in an area where your own success
and  <u>achievement are especially important.</u> Receiving
help  with  a  self-relevant  task  can  make  you  feel  bad
about yourself, and this can  <u>undermine the potential
positive  effects  of  the  help.</u>  For  example,  if  your  self-
concept rests, in part, on your great cooking ability, it
may be a  <u>blow to your ego when a friend helps you
prepare a meal for guests because it suggests that you’re
not the master chef you thought you were.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Psychologist  Christopher  Bryan  finds  that  when  we
shift our emphasis from behavior to character, people
evaluate choices  <u>differently.</u> His team was able to
cut cheating in half: instead of “Please don’t cheat,”
they changed the appeal to “Please don’t be a cheater.”
When you’re urged not to cheat, you can do it and still
see an  <u>ethnic person in the mirror.</u> But when you’re
told  not  to  be  a  cheater,  the  act  casts  a  shadow;
immorality is tied to your identity, making the behavior
much  <u>less attractive.</u> Cheating is an isolated action
that gets evaluated with the logic of consequence: Can
I get away with it? Being a cheater evokes a sense of
self, triggering the logic of appropriateness: What kind
of person am I, and who do I want to be? In light of
this  evidence,  Bryan  suggests  that  we  should 
<u>embrace  nouns  more  thoughtfully.</u>  “Don’t  Drink  and
Drive”  could  be  rephrased  as:  “Don’t  Be  a  Drunk
Driver.”  The  same  thinking  can  be  applied  to 
<u>originality.</u>  When  a  child  draws  a  picture,  instead  of
calling  the  artwork  creative,  we  can  say  “You  are
creative.”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
One benefit of reasons and arguments is that they can
foster  humility.  If  two  people  <u>disagree without
arguing, all they do is yell at each other.</u> No progress is
made. Both still think that they are right. In contrast, if
both sides give arguments that  <u>articulate reasons for
their positions, then new possibilities open up.</u> One of the
arguments gets refuted – that is, it is shown to fail. In
that  case,  the  person  who  depended  on  the  refuted
argument learns that he needs to change his view. That
is one way to achieve humility – on one side at least.
Another possibility is that  <u>either argument is refuted.</u>
Both  have  a  degree  of  reason  on  their  side.  Even  if
neither  person  involved  is  convinced  by  the  other’s
argument,  both  can  still  come  to  <u>appreciate the
opposing view.</u> They also realize that, even if they have
some truth, they do not have the whole truth. They can
gain  humility  when  they  recognize  and  appreciate  the
reasons  <u>against their own view.</u>

explanation: 겸손함을 얻기 위한 두 가지 방법에 대한 글로, 첫 번째는 한쪽의 주장이 반박되어 그 주장에 의지했던 사람이 자신 의 생각을 바꾸는 것이고, 두 번째는 양쪽의 주장이 모두 어느 정 도의 타당성을 가지고 있어서 어느 쪽도 상대방의 주장에 설득되 지 않지만, 양쪽 모두 상대방의 의견을 존중하게 되는 경우이다. 따라서, 두 번째 가능성에서는 'either' 대신 'neither'를 사용하여 '양쪽의 주장이 모두 반박되지 않는 경우'를 나타내는 것이 적절하 다. 따라서 ③ 'either'를 'neither'로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the  next.  This  is  different  from  acclimation  —  an
individual  organism’s  changes  in  response  to  an 
<u>altered  environment.</u>  For  example,  if  you  spend  the
summer outside, you may acclimate to the sunlight:
your  skin  will  <u>decrease  its  concentration  of  dark
pigments that protect you from the sun.</u> This is a 
<u>temporary change, and you won’t pass the transient
change on to future generations.</u> However, the capacity
to produce skin pigments is inherited. For populations
living in intensely sunny environments, individuals with
a good ability to produce skin pigments are more likely
to thrive, or to survive, than people with a poor ability
to  produce  pigments,  and  that  trait  becomes
increasingly  <u>common in subsequent generations.</u> If
you look around, you can find countless examples of 
<u>adaptation.</u> The distinctive long neck of a giraffe, for
example,  developed  as  individuals  that  happened  to
have longer necks had an advantage in feeding on the
leaves of tall trees.

text:
Adaptation  involves  changes  in  a  population,  with
characteristics that are passed from one generation to
the  next.  This  is  different  from  acclimation  —  an
individual  organism’s  changes  in  response  to  an 
<u>altered  environment.</u>  For  example,  if  you  spend  the
summer outside, you may acclimate to the sunlight:
your  skin  will  <u>decrease  its  concentration  of  dark
pigments that protect you from the sun.</u> This is a 
<u>temporary change, and you won’t pass the transient
change on to future generations.</u> However, the capacity
to produce skin pigments is inherited. For populations
living in intensely sunny environments, individuals with
a good ability to produce skin pigments are more likely
to thrive, or to survive, than people with a poor ability
to  produce  pigments,  and  that  trait  becomes
increasingly  <u>common in subsequent generations.</u> If
you look around, you can find countless examples of 
<u>adaptation.</u> The distinctive long neck of a giraffe, for
example,  developed  as  individuals  that  happened  to
have longer necks had an advantage in feeding on the
leaves of tall trees. 
* pigment: 색소
options: ① <u>altered  environment.</u>

② <u>decrease  its  concentration  of  dark
pigments that protect you from the sun.</u>

③ <u>temporary change, and you won’t pass the transient
change on to future generations.</u>
④ <u>common in subsequent generations.</u>
⑤ <u>adaptation.</u>
explanation: 여름을 야외에서 보낸다면 햇빛에 순응하게 되고, 피부를 보호하기 위해 어두운 색소의 농도를 높인다는 것이 흐름 상 적절하므로 ② decreases를 increases 등으로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Greenwashing  involves  fooling  a  consumer  into
thinking  a  good  or  service  is  more  environmentally
friendly  than  it  really  is.  Greenwashing  ranges  from
making  environmental  claims  required  by  law,  and
therefore irrelevant (CFC-free for example), to puffery
(exaggerating environmental claims) to  <u>deception.</u>
Researchers have shown that claims on products are
often  too  vague  or  misleading;  for  example,  some
products are labeled "chemical-free," when the fact is
everything  is  <u>comprised of  chemicals,  including
plants and animals.</u> Products with the highest number
of  misleading  or  unverifiable  claims  were  laundry
detergents, household cleaners, and paints. The most
common reason for greenwashing is to  <u>appeal to
environmentally   conscious   consumers.</u>   These
consumers  are  likely  to  buy  eco-friendly  goods  and
they usually do not find out about the false claims until
after  the  purchase  of  greenwashing  products.
Therefore, using greenwashing strategy may  <u>lower
sales  of  those  products  temporarily.</u>  However,  this
strategy  can  seriously  backfire  when  consumers  find
out  they  are  being  misinformed.  Nowadays,
environmental advocates agree on providing shoppers
with  <u>sufficient information about the products they
buy so that they can be aware of the environmental
impact of them.</u>
* CFC: 염화불화탄소
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

We usually take time out only when we really need to
switch  off,  and  when  this  happens  we  are  often
overtired, sick, and in need of recuperation. Me time is
complicated  by (A)   [positive   /   unfavorable]
associations with escapism, guilt, and regret as well as
overwhelm,  stress,  and  fatigue.  All  these  negative
connotations mean we tend to steer clear of (a) it.
Well,  I  am  about  to  change  your  perception  of  the
importance  of  me  time,  to  persuade  you  that  you
should  view (b) it as  vital  for  your  health  and
wellbeing. Take this as (B) [refusal / permission] to
set aside some time for yourself! Our need for time in
which  to  do  what  we  choose  is  increasingly (C)

overwhelmed, and overstimulated world.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news out
of  the  way  is  attempting  to  soften  it  or  simply  not
address it at all. This “Mum Effect” – a term coined by
psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in the
early  1970s – happens  because  people  tend  not  to
 <u>avoid being the target of others’ negative emotions.</u>
We all have the opportunity to lead change, yet it often
requires of us the courage to  <u>deliver bad news to our
superiors.</u> We don’t want to be the innocent messenger
who falls before a firing line. When our survival instincts
kick in, they can  <u>dismiss our courage until the truth of
a situation gets watered down.</u> “The Mum Effect and the
resulting  <u>filtering can have devastating effects in a
rigid hierarchy,” writes Robert Sutton, an organizational
psychologist.</u>  “What  starts  out  as  bad  news  becomes
happier and happier as it travels up the ranks – because
after  each  boss  hears  the  news  from  his  or  her
subordinates, he or she makes it sound a bit  <u>less bad
before passing it up the chain.</u>”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
There are several reasons why support may not  <u>be
effective.</u>  One  possible  reason  is  that  receiving  help
could  be  a  blow  to  self‐esteem.  A  recent  study  by
Christopher  Burke  and  Jessica  Goren  at  Lehigh
University examined this possibility. According to the
threat to self‐esteem model, help can be perceived as
supportive and loving, or it can be seen as threatening
if  that  help  is  interpreted  as  implying  <u>incapacity.</u>
According  to  Burke  and  Goren,  support  is  especially
likely to be seen as threatening if it is in an area that is
self‐relevant  or  self‐defining  —  that  is,  in  an  area
where  your  own  success  and  achievement  are
especially  <u>insignificant.</u> Receiving help with a self‐
relevant task can make you feel bad about yourself,
and  this  can  <u>make  worse  the  potential  positive
effects of the help.</u> For example, if your self‐concept
rests, in part, on your great cooking ability, it may be
 <u>a  damage  to  your  ego  when  a  friend  helps  you
prepare  a  meal  for  guests  because  it  suggests  that
you’re not the master chef you thought you were.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Psychologist Christopher Bryan finds that when we 
<u>shift our emphasis from behavior to character, people
evaluate choices differently.</u> His team was able to cut
cheating in half: instead of “Please don’t cheat,” they
changed  the  appeal  to  “Please  don’t  be  a  cheater.”
When you’re  <u>urged not to cheat, you can do it and
still  see  an  ethical  person  in  the  mirror.</u>  But  when
you’re told not to be a cheater, the act casts a shadow;
immorality  is  <u>tied  to  your  identity,  making  the
behavior much less attractive.</u> Cheating is an isolated
action  that  gets  evaluated  with  the  logic  of
consequence: Can I get away with it? Being a cheater
 <u>represses  a  sense  of  self,  triggering  the  logic  of
appropriateness: What kind of person am I, and who
do  I  want  to  be?</u>  In  light  of  this  evidence,  Bryan
suggests  that  we  should  <u>embrace  nouns  more
thoughtfully.</u>  “Don’t  Drink  and  Drive”  could  be
rephrased  as:  “Don’t  Be  a  Drunk  Driver.”  The  same
thinking  can  be  applied  to  originality.  When  a  child
draws a picture, instead of calling the artwork creative,
we can say “You are creative.”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
One benefit of reasons and arguments is that they can
 <u>promote  humility.</u>  If  two  people  disagree  without
arguing, all they do is yell at each other. No progress is
made.  Both  still  think  that  they  are  <u>valid.</u>  In
contrast, if both sides give arguments that articulate
reasons for their positions, then new possibilities open
up. One of the arguments gets refuted — that is, it is
shown  to  <u>fail.</u>  In  that  case,  the  person  who
depended  on  the  refuted  argument  learns  that  he
needs to  <u>maintain  his view.</u> That is one way to
achieve  humility  —on  one  side  at  least.  Another
possibility  is  that  neither  argument  is  refuted.  Both
have a degree of reason on their side. Even if neither
person involved is convinced by the other’s argument,
both can still come to appreciate the  <u>opposing view.</u>
They also realize that, even if they have some truth,
they  do  not  have  the  whole  truth.  They  can  gain
humility  when  they  recognize  and  appreciate  the
reasons against their own view.
*articulate: 분명히 말하다 **humility: 겸손

Environmental advocates agree there is still a long way
to  go  to  ensure  shoppers  are  adequately  informed
about the environmental impact of the products they
buy. The most common reason for greenwashing is to
attract  environmentally  conscious  consumers.  Many
consumers   do   not   find   out   about   the
 <u>incorrect claims until after the purchase.</u> Therefore,
greenwashing  may  increase  sales  <u>permanently.</u>
However,  this  strategy  can  seriously  backfire  when
consumers find out they are being  <u>misinformed.</u>
*CFC: 염화불화탄소 **fraud: 사기
text:
Greenwashing  involves  misleading  a  consumer  into
thinking  a  good  or  service  is  more  environmentally
friendly  than  it  really  is.  Greenwashing  ranges  from
making  environmental  claims  required  by  law,  and
therefore  <u>irrelevant  (CFC‐free  for  example),  to
puffery (exaggerating environmental claims) to fraud.</u>
Researchers have shown that claims on products are
often  too  vague  or  misleading.  Some  products  are
labeled   “chemical‐free,”   when   the   fact   is
 <u>everything contains chemicals, including plants and
animals.</u>  Products  with  the  highest  number  of
misleading  or  unverifiable  claims  were  laundry
detergents,   household   cleaners,   and   paints.
Environmental advocates agree there is still a long way
to  go  to  ensure  shoppers  are  adequately  informed
about the environmental impact of the products they
buy. The most common reason for greenwashing is to
attract  environmentally  conscious  consumers.  Many
consumers   do   not   find   out   about   the
 <u>incorrect claims until after the purchase.</u> Therefore,
greenwashing  may  increase  sales  <u>permanently.</u>
However,  this  strategy  can  seriously  backfire  when
consumers find out they are being  <u>misinformed.</u>
*CFC: 염화불화탄소 **fraud: 사기
options:
① <u>irrelevant  (CFC‐free  for  example),  to
puffery (exaggerating environmental claims) to fraud.</u>

② <u>everything contains chemicals, including plants and
animals.</u>
③ <u>incorrect claims until after the purchase.</u>
④ <u>permanently.</u>
⑤ <u>misinformed.</u>
explanation: 그린워싱은 소비자들이 친환경적이라고 여기고 제 품을 구매하도록 현혹하는 것으로, 소비자들은 구매가 완료되고 나서야 거짓 주장을 확인할 수 있게 된다고 했다. 따라서 판매량은 증가시킬 수 있겠지만, 나중에 소비자들이 자신들이 속고 있다는 것을 알게 될 때 심각할 정도로 역효과를 낳을 수 있다고 하였으므 로 ④ permanently(영구적으로, 영원히)를 in the short term(단기적으로) 등으로 고쳐야 한다. [원문: ③ false ⑤ deceived]

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하 지 않은 것은? (2개)
mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news
out  of  the  way  is  attempting  to  <u>euphemize  it  or
simply  not  address  it  at  all.</u>  This  “Mum  Effect”  —  a
term  coined  by  psychologists  Sidney  Rosen  and
Abraham Tesser in the early 1970s — happens because
people want to avoid becoming the target of others’ 
<u>aggressive emotions.</u> We all have the opportunity to
lead change, yet it often requires of us the courage to
 <u>conceal bad news to our superiors.</u> We don’t want to
be  the  innocent  messenger  who  falls  before  a  firing
line.  When  our  survival  instincts  kick  in,  they  can
override our courage until the truth of a situation gets
watered down. “The Mum Effect and the  <u>consequent
filtering  can  have  devastating  effects  in  a  steep
hierarchy,”  writes  Robert  Sutton,  an  organizational
psychologist.</u> “What starts out as bad news becomes
happier  and  happier  as  it  travels  up  the  ranks  ―
because after each boss hears the news from his or
her subordinates, he or she makes it sound a bit 
<u>more serious before passing it up the chain.</u>”

explanation: 나쁜 소식을 전달할 용기가 적절하므로 ③ conceal[가리다, 숨기다]을 deliver[전달하다]등으로 고쳐야 한 다. 침묵 효과 때문에 가파른 위계 조직에서 나쁜 소식이 정확히 빠르게 전달되지 못하게 되므로, 단계를 올라갈 수록 그 소식은 덜 나쁘게 들린다는 맥락이 적절하다. 따라서 ⑤ 'more serious'는 'less bed'등으로 바꿔야 한다. [오답노트] ① 완곡하게 표현하다, ② 공격적인, ④ 그 결과로 발생하는
